{{About|the chapter of the Gospel of Mark||Mark XV (disambiguation){{!}}Mark XV}} {{Infobox bible chapter | name= Mark 15 | previouslink=Mark 14 |previous=chapter 14 | nextlink= Mark 16 |next= chapter 16 | book=[[Gospel of Mark]] | biblepart=[[New Testament]] | booknum=2 | category= [[Gospel]] | image=Uncial 059 (Mk 15,29-33).JPG | caption=Fragment of Uncial 059 (4th/5th century) showing Mark 15:29-33. }} {{Chapters in the Gospel of Mark}} '''Mark 15''' is the fifteenth chapter of the [[Gospel of Mark]] in the [[New Testament]] of the [[Christian]] [[Bible]]. It continues [[Jesus]]' [[Passion (Christianity)|passion]], including his [[Pilate's court|trial before Pontius Pilate]] and then his [[Crucifixion of Christ|crucifixion, death]] and [[Entombment of Christ|entombment]].
==Structure== The [[New King James Version]] organises this chapter as follows: *{{bibleverse||Mark|15:1-5|NKJV}} = Jesus faces Pilate *{{bibleverse||Mark|15:6-15|NKJV}} = Taking the Place of Barabbas *{{bibleverse||Mark|15:16-20|NKJV}} = The Soldiers Mock Jesus *{{bibleverse||Mark|15:21-32|NKJV}} = The King on a Cross *{{bibleverse||Mark|15:33-41|NKJV}} = Jesus Dies on the Cross *{{bibleverse||Mark|15:42-47|NKJV}} = Jesus Buried in Joseph’s Tomb
== Trial before Pilate == {{main|Pilate's court}} It is early in the morning. The [[Sanhedrin Trial of Jesus|Sanhedrin reaches a decision]] and hands Jesus over to [[Pontius Pilate]]. Pilate was the Roman [[Prefect]] (governor) of [[Iudaea Province#Iudaea|Iudaea Province]] from 26 to 36, which was the Roman combination of [[Idumea]], [[Judea]] and [[Samaria]] and did not include [[Galilee]], which was under the jurisdiction of [[Herod Antipas]]. According to [[Gospel of Matthew|Matthew]], the Sanhedrin had decided to [[Capital punishment|execute]] Jesus. Only the [[Roman Empire|Romans]] were allowed to execute someone, not the local officials, according to [[John 18:31]], yet {{bibleverse||Acts|6:12}} records the [[Sanhedrin]] ordering the [[stoning]] of [[Saint Stephen]] and also [[James the Just]] according to [[Antiquities of the Jews]] (20.9.1), resulting in a rebuke from the Roman authority.<ref>[http://earlyjewishwritings.com/text/josephus/ant20.html Josephus, ''Antiquities of the Jews'', 20.9.1]</ref>
===Verse 2=== : ''Pilate asked him, 'Are you the [[Jesus, King of the Jews|King of the Jews]]?' :: ''He answered him, 'You say so.' ''(NRSV)<ref>{{bibleverse||Mark|15:2|NRSV}}</ref>
====Verse 2 in Greek==== [[Textus Receptus]]/[[Byzantine text-type|Majority Text]]: : καὶ ἐπηρώτησεν αὐτὸν ὁ Πιλάτος, Σὺ εἶ ὁ βασιλεὺς τῶν Ἰουδαίων; :: ὁ δὲ ἀποκριθεὶς εἶπεν αὐτῷ, Σὺ λέγεις.
Cross reference: [[Matthew 27:11]]; [[Luke 23:3]]; [[John 18:37]]
An interpretation is that Pilate is asking Jesus if he is the [[messiah]], just as the [[List of High Priests of Israel|high priest]] before in {{bibleverse||Mark|14:61}}, only with an explicit emphasis on the Messiah's political role, that of Jewish King.<ref name="Brown et al. 627">Brown ''et al.'' 627</ref> According to [[Gospel of John|John's gospel]], in response to Pilate's question Jesus has a short conversation with Pilate and then answers, "You are right in saying I am a king. In fact, for this reason I was born, and for this I came into the world, to testify to the truth. Everyone on the side of truth listens to me." [[Historical Jesus|Historically]] it is likely that perceived [[insurrection]] against [[Roman Empire|Rome]] was for what Pilate executed Jesus.<ref>Brown et al. 628</ref> According to {{bibleverse||Mark|12:17}}, however, Jesus said one should [[Render unto Caesar...|pay the Roman tax]] and was thus not a [[Zealot|revolutionary]]. The 1985 [[Jesus Seminar]] reached the conclusion that the [[Jesus and the Money Changers|temple incident]] was the cause of the crucifixion.
===Verse 3=== The chief priests make several further, unspecified, allegations, "heaping accusations on Him".<ref>[http://biblehub.com/wey/mark/15.htm Mark 15:3], Weymouth New Testament</ref> Some manuscripts state here that Jesus gives no reply.<ref>[http://biblehub.com/commentaries/pulpit/mark/15.htm Pulpit Commentary on Mark 15], accessed 27 June 2017</ref> Pilate pushes him for one but he still remains silent, which amazes or surprises Pilate. According to [[Gospel of Luke|Luke]], Pilate at this point sent Jesus to [[Herod Antipas]] because Jesus, as a Galilean, was under Herod's jurisdiction. Herod was excited to see Jesus at first, but ended up mocking him and sending him back to Pilate.
===Release of Barabbas=== According to Mark's account, it was a custom to release a prisoner at [[Passover]], which was a celebration of freedom. No other historical record of the time records Pilate doing this, and he is known to have been cruel, for which he was eventually expelled from his post.<ref>Kilgallen 281</ref> ([http://earlyjewishwritings.com/text/josephus/ant18.html JA18].4.2) All the other [[Gospel]]s however also agree with Mark on this tradition. Some theologians suggest that Pilate did this once or a few times <ref name="Brown et al. 627"/> or that the Gospels accurately record this tradition even though other sources fail to mention. The [[Jesus Seminar]] argued doing this during a volatile situation like this would have been unlikely.<ref>Miller 49</ref>
According to Matthew, Pilate received a message from his [[Pontius Pilate's wife|wife]] that she believed Jesus was innocent because of a disturbing dream she had just had. He asks the crowd if they want the King of the Jews released to them because, according to Mark, Pilate knew the priests were [[envy|envious]] of Jesus and so presumably wanted to free him without a fight with them.
[[File:Eccehomo2.jpg|thumb|right|175px|''Ecce Homo'' (''Behold, the Man!''), [[Antonio Ciseri]], 19th century: Pontius Pilate presents a scourged Jesus of Nazareth to onlookers]]
The priests however convince the crowd to ask for the release of [[Barabbas]], a prisoner. Mark says he was in prison chained "with" insurrectionists who had committed murder during a recent στασισ (''stasis'', a riot), probably "one of ... numerous insurrections against the Roman power" <ref>[http://biblehub.com/commentaries/cambridge/mark/15.htm Cambridge Bible for Schools and Colleges on Mark 15], accessed 11 December 2017</ref> Theologian [[John Gill (theologian)|John Gill]] says he was "at the head" of the rebels.<ref>[http://biblehub.com/commentaries/gill/mark/15.htm Gill's Exposition of Mark 15], accessed 11 December 2017</ref> Both Luke and John say he was a [[zealots|revolutionary]]. Jesus seems to have already been declared guilty as this seems a choice between releasing two prisoners.<ref name="Brown et al. 627"/>
Pilate then asks what should be done with Jesus. They say he should be crucified, but Pilate asks what he is guilty of. They still demand he be crucified so Pilate turns Barabbas over to the crowd and has Jesus [[Flagellation|flogged]] and then sent out to be crucified. Matthew has Pilate washing his hands and declaring the crowd responsible, which the crowd accepts.
For his flogging Jesus would have been tied to a pillar, and hit with [[bone]] or [[metal]] studded [[whip]]s.<ref name="Brown et al. 628">Brown ''et al.'' 628</ref> Crucifixion was a particularly shameful form of death, with a stigma put onto even the condemned's family.<ref>Kilgallen 284</ref>
Roman magistrates had wide discretion in executing their tasks, and some question whether Pilate would have been so captive to the demands of the crowd. Summarily executing someone to calm the situation however would have been a tool a Roman governor would have used.<ref>Miller 49–50</ref>
== The soldiers mock Jesus == [[File:Mathis Gothart Grünewald 062.jpg|thumb|left|200px|<center>[[The Mocking of Christ (Grünewald)|The Mocking of Christ by Grünewald]]</center>]] {{main|Mocking of Jesus}} Mark says the soldiers took Jesus to the [[Praetorium]], either [[Herod's Palace (Jerusalem)|Herod's palace]] or the [[Antonia Fortress|Fortress Antonia]].<ref name="Brown et al. 628"/> They gather together all the other soldiers. These were probably mostly recruits from the area of Palestine or Syria.<ref name="Brown et al. 628"/>
The soldiers put a [[purple]] robe on Jesus and put a [[crown of thorns]] on his head and mockingly hail him as the [[Jesus, King of the Jews|King of the Jews]]. They hit him in the head with a staff and pay fake [[Homage (feudal)|homage]] to him. According to Matthew they put the staff in his hand first before beating him with it. They dress him in his own clothes and take him out to be crucified. According to John they left his purple robe and crown on.
Jesus is given the trappings of a King. Purple is a [[Tyrian purple|royal color]]. He wears a crown and is hit with a staff, also a royal [[symbol]]. This whole scene is colored with [[Divinity|divine]] [[irony]], as everything the soldiers do to mock Jesus' claim of being a King is used by Mark to show this, at the height of the Passion, as Jesus' crowning as messiah according to [[God]]'s plan.<ref>Miller 50</ref>
According to John after the [[Flagellation of Christ|flogging]] Pilate brought Jesus back a second time and tried to convince the crowd that he was innocent but the crowd still demanded Jesus' death and so then Pilate had him crucified. Luke has no account of the soldiers beating Jesus.
== Jesus' crucifixion == [[File:Giovanni Battista Tiepolo 075.jpg|thumb|right|200px|<center>The Way of the Cross of Christ, Ascent to Calvary by [[Giovanni Battista Tiepolo]]]] [[File:Israel 5 010 Via Dolorosa- Walk in Jerusalem, with Jesus Christ-Actor and Press.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Reenacting the [[Stations of the Cross]] in [[Jerusalem in Christianity|Jerusalem]] on the [[Via Dolorosa]] from the [[Lions' Gate]] to the [[Church of the Holy Sepulchre]].]] [[File:Golgotha cross-section.svg|thumb|200px|right|A diagram of the Church of the Holy Sepulchre based on a German documentary, claimed to be the site of [[Calvary]] and the [[Tomb of Jesus]].]] [[File:Albrecht Altdorfer 016.jpg|thumb|right|200px|<center>Crucifixion of Christ by [[Albrecht Altdorfer]]]] {{main|Crucifixion of Jesus}}
On the way to their final destination the soldiers force a man passing by, [[Simon of Cyrene]], to carry Jesus' cross for him, though Mark does not say why. [[Cyrene, Libya|Cyrene]] was in North [[Africa]] and Simon would have moved from there or would have been visiting. Mark lists his children, Alexander and Rufus. That Mark takes the time to list only their names suggests they might have been [[Early Christians]] known to Mark's intended audience.<ref name="Brown et al. 628"/> [[Paul of Tarsus|Paul]] also lists a Rufus in [[Epistle to the Romans|Romans]] [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?book_id=52&chapter=16&version=31 16:13]. Luke has Jesus talking to some of his women followers along the way.
They arrive at [[Aramaic of Jesus#Golgotha .28.CE.93.CE.BF.CE.BB.CE.B3.CE.BF.CE.B8.CE.B1.29|Golgotha]], which Mark says means the place of the [[skull]]. This was probably an exhausted rock quarry whose remaining rock had been damaged in an earthquake.<ref>Kilgallen 286</ref>
They offer Jesus [[wine]] laced with [[myrrh]] to lessen the pain, but he refuses. Mark then simply says they crucified him. They then take his clothes and divide lots to distribute them. People have seen a relationship with this and Psalm [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?book_id=23&chapter=22&version=31 22:18], which John actually quotes as a fulfillment of [[prophecy]].
According to Mark, it was the "third hour" when Jesus was crucified. This would be the third hour of daylight, or about 9:00 AM. John however says Jesus was condemned to death around the sixth hour, or [[noon]]. The charge listed on Jesus' cross is "THE KING OF THE JEWS" ([[INRI]]) According to John, the chief priests complained to Pilate about this but he refused to change the charge.
Two [[Theft|robbers]] were also crucified on each side of him and according to Mark 15, both of them mocked Jesus, even when they were in their processes of death. Luke reports the robbers' conversation with Jesus. People come by and insult Jesus and mock him for claiming he would destroy and then rebuild [[Herod's Temple]] in three days, which Jesus has not said so far in Mark but was falsely accused of claiming to destroy the "man-made" Temple and rebuilt it in three days in Mark [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?book_id=48&chapter=14&version=31 14:57–58]. The chief priests are also there and say that if he is really the [[Christ]] then he should be able to come down from the cross and save himself as he had saved others, a reference to his many [[Miracles of Jesus|miracles]] earlier in Mark.
Mark relates these two mockings to perhaps highlight the question of why, if Jesus is indeed the messiah, can he not save himself from being put to death. Mark refutes these two charges later when Jesus rebuilds the Temple of his body and not only overcomes the cross but death itself in Mark [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?book_id=48&chapter=16&version=31 16].<ref>Kilgallen 288</ref> Mark might be stressing that if one follows Jesus, who Mark believes is the messiah, then one can expect help from God, such as Jesus' miracles, but one will not be saved from the pains of this world, and indeed in some way they are necessary to achieve a greater goal as Jesus' death is necessary for his role as the messiah.{{citation needed|date=January 2015}}
== The death of Jesus == {{see also|Sayings of Jesus on the cross}} [[File:Uncial 0184 Mk 15,36–37.40-41.jpg| 250px|thumb|right |[[Gospel of Mark|Mark]] 15:36-37,40-41in [[Greek language|Greek]]-[[Coptic language|Coptic]] from [[Uncial 0184]] (Vindobonensis Pap. K. 8662; 6th century).]] According to Mark: :''And when the sixth hour was come, there was darkness over the whole land until the ninth hour. And at the ninth hour Jesus cried with a loud voice, saying, [[Aramaic of Jesus#Eli Eli lema sabachthani .28.CE.97.CE.BB.CE.B5.CE.B9 .CE.97.CE.BB.CE.B5.CE.B9 .CE.BB.CE.B5.CE.BC.CE.B1 .CF.83.CE.B1.CE.B2.CE.B1.CF.87.CE.B8.CE.B1.CE.BD.CE.B5.CE.B9.29|Eloi, Eloi, lama sabachthani]]? which is, being interpreted, My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me? And some of them that stood by, when heard it, said, Behold, he calleth [[Elijah|Elias]]. And one ran and filled a spunge full of [[vinegar]], and put it on a [[Phragmites|reed]], and gave him to drink, saying, Let alone; let us see whether Elias will come to take him down. And Jesus cried with a loud voice, and gave up the [[soul|ghost]]. And the veil of the temple was rent in twain from the top to the bottom. And when the [[Centurion (Roman army)|centurion]], which stood over against him, saw that he so cried out, and gave up the ghost, he said, Truly this man was the Son of God.''
The soldier might be recognizing something that no one else could and thus vindicating Jesus,<ref name="Brown 147">Brown 147</ref> or he might be saying this [[Sarcasm|sarcastically]].<ref>Miller 51</ref> This statement may bring the Gospel full circle to {{bibleverse||Mark|1:1|31}} where Jesus is identified by the writer as "the Son of God" (only in some versions, see [[Mark 1]] for details). Luke records that he said that Jesus was a [[righteous]] man. Matthew adds that at the moment of Jesus' death tombs in Jerusalem were opened and many bodies of "the [[saints]]" were raised from the dead. They were seen subsequently in the "holy city," Jerusalem, by many ({{bibleverse||Matthew|27:53–54|31}}).
The veil of the Temple was the barrier between the inner Temple, thought to be God's place on Earth, and the rest. Its destruction is a vindication of Jesus. This might be a [[metaphor]] for God now no longer being separated but free for all the world.<ref>Kilgallen 291</ref> Given the imagery of the temple veil (there were cherubim woven into it, like the cherub set as guard over the entrance to Eden after Adam and Eve were cast out) as a symbol of the barrier between the Holy God and sinful men, the rending of the veil indicates a propitiation of God's wrath.{{citation needed|date=January 2015}}
According to John, Jesus' mother [[Mary the mother of Jesus|Mary]] and her sister Mary were there with the [[Disciple whom Jesus loved]] and Jesus told the disciple to take Mary into his home.{{citation needed|date=January 2015}}
== Jesus' entombment == ''For the subject in art, see [[Entombment of Christ]]'' [[File:Pieter Lastman - Graflegging.jpg|thumb|left|200px|<center>Entombment of Christ by [[Pieter Lastman]]]]
It is notable that, according to Mark, it is only Jesus' women followers who are now still with him:
:''Some women were watching from a distance. Among them were [[Mary Magdalene]], Mary the mother of James the younger and of [[Joses]], and [[Salome (disciple)|Salome]]. In Galilee these women had followed him and cared for his needs. Many other women who had come up with him to Jerusalem were also there.'' ([http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Mark%2015:40–41;&version=31; 40–41])
Mary Magdalene has not been mentioned so far in Mark, and the other Mary is perhaps Jesus' mother Mary as she is also mentioned as James' mother in Mark [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?book_id=48&chapter=6&version=31 6:3]. She could also be another Mary, perhaps another relative.<ref>Kilgallen 293</ref> Salome was [[Saint James the Great|James]]' and [[John the Apostle|John]]'s mother. The fact the Mark has not explicitly related any of Jesus' interaction with them shows that Mark has left out many of the events of the life of the "[[Historical Jesus]]" and only related events he deems necessary to make his points about Jesus.<ref>Kilgallen 294</ref>
John says the soldiers were told to take down the bodies for the Sabbath and broke the other two men's legs but stabbed Jesus with a spear to make sure he was dead. John claims this is eye witness testimony.
Evening is approaching and [[Joseph of Arimathea]], a member of the [[sanhedrin]], who was also waiting for the "[[Kingdom of God]]," goes to Pilate and asks for Jesus' body. The Scholars Version<ref>Miller, p. 51</ref> notes this as "unexpected .. Is Joseph in effect bringing Jesus into his family?" As the next day was the [[Shabbat|Sabbath]] Jesus would have to have been buried before sundown or then not until the next night. According to [[613 Commandments|Mosaic law]], if someone was hanged on a tree they were not to remain there at night.<ref name="Brown 147"/> ({{bibleverse||Deuteronomy|21:22–23}}) Pilate is surprised Jesus had died so soon and asks for confirmation, and then gives Jesus' body to Joseph.
Joseph wraps it in [[linen]] and puts it in a [[sepulchre]], rolls a stone over the entrance, and leaves. According to John, he was assisted by the Pharisee [[Nicodemus]]. The two Marys witness the burial, or at any rate the location where Jesus' body was buried: German biblical commentators [[Heinrich August Wilhelm Meyer|Meyer]] and [[Bernhard Weiss|Weiss]] infer from the Greek [[perfect tense]] τέθειται (''tetheitai'', he was laid) that "the women were not present at the burial, but simply approached and took note where Jesus lay after burial".<ref>[http://biblehub.com/commentaries/egt/mark/15.htm Expositor's Greek Testament on Mark 15], accessed 12 December 2017</ref> Bodies were normally anointed, but there seems to be no time here. John however says Nicodemus wrapped up Jesus' body with spices, which seems to indicate an anointing. The tomb, one of many around Jerusalem, was a [[limestone]] [[cave]] and Jesus' body would have been laid on a pre-cut shelf, and then most bodies would have been left for a year.<ref name="Brown et al. 628"/>
Jesus' trial before Pilate and his crucifixion, death, and burial are also found in [[Matthew 27|Matthew]] [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?book_id=47&chapter=27&version=31 27], Luke [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?book_id=49&chapter=23&version=31 23], and John [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=John%2018:28–19:42;&version=31; 18:28–19:42].
==See also== * [[Crucifixion of Jesus]] * [[Pilate's court]] * [[Rufus (biblical figure)]] * Related [[Bible]] parts: [[Matthew 27]], [[Luke 23]], [[John 18]], [[John 19]], [[Romans 16]]

{{For|the traditional Jewish food|matzah ball}}
The '''Matzo Ball''' is an annual [[Christmas Eve]] nightlife event and party held in a number of major cities in the United States and Canada targeted primarily at young [[Jewish]] [[single person|singles]] and organized by the Society of Young Jewish Professionals.<ref name="AP2006">[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/12/23/AR2006122300971.html Jessica Gresko, ''Dec. 24 Becomes Party Night for Jewish Singles'', Associated Press (Washington Post), December 24, 2006]</ref><ref name="Canada">[http://www.jewishtribune.ca/TribuneV2/index.php/200911102313/Famous-Matzo-Ball-parties-to-land-here.html Mike Cohen, ''Famous Matzo Ball parties to land here'', Jewish Tribune (Canada), November 10, 2009] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091127060521/http://www.jewishtribune.ca/TribuneV2/index.php/200911102313/Famous-Matzo-Ball-parties-to-land-here.html |date=November 27, 2009 }}</ref>
The name of the event is frequently styled as '''MatzoBall'''<ref name="JTA2002">[http://www.jweekly.com/article/full/18992/christmas-time-inspires-jews-to-express-own-jewishness Joe Berkofsky, ''Christmas time inspires Jews 'to express own Jewishness' '', JTA (Jewish Telegraphic Agency), reprinted in j. the Jewish news weekly of Northern California, December 20, 2002]</ref><ref name="DetroitMetromix">[http://detroit.metromix.com/events/photogallery/party-pics-12th-annual/858010/photo/858201 ''Party pics: 12th Annual MatzoBall party'', MetroMix.com, 2008]</ref><ref name=Kirchick /> or misspelled as '''Matzah Ball'''<ref name="JTA2002"/><ref name="Rhythmism">[http://www.rhythmism.com/forum/showthread.php?t=87415 ''The Matzah Ball at KISS & FLY - Thursday, Dec 24th 2009'', Rhythmism.com - Upcoming Events forum, 2009] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715181855/http://www.rhythmism.com/forum/showthread.php?t=87415 |date=2011-07-15 }}</ref> or '''MatzahBall'''.<ref name="Exponent">[http://www.jewishexponent.com/article/18001/ Roy S. Gutterman, ''Hitting the Road to Check Out the Scene During Holiday Season'', The (Philadelphia) Jewish Exponent, January 8, 2009]</ref><ref name="PRRelease">[http://www.prwebdirect.com/releases/2005/12/prweb324564.htm Society of Young Jewish Professionals, Press Release: ''Record 10,000 Jewish Singles to Attend Matzo Ball Parties on December 24'', PRWebDirect.com, December 20, 2005] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060218151157/http://www.prwebdirect.com/releases/2005/12/prweb324564.htm |date=February 18, 2006 }}</ref>
There are a number of [[#Competitors|competing social events in Jewish communities throughout the U.S. and Canada]] held that same night. In addition, '''Matzo Ball''' and similar spellings are also used as the names for a [[#Similarly Named Events Unaffiliated with SYJP|variety of other, unrelated Jewish community events in particular regions]].
==Background==
===Historical=== {{see also|Nittel Nacht}} Historically, Jews in Europe would hide in their homes and villages during the Christmas holiday, for fear of violence from locals.<ref name="JTA2009">[http://jta.org/news/article/2009/12/17/1009795/w ''What’s a Jew to do on Christmas Eve?'', JTA (Jewish Telegraphic Agency), December 17, 2009]</ref> In the United States, Christmas and Christmas Eve typically serve as times of family gathering and prayer for Christians and many others.<ref name="TimesSeason">[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C0DE1DA143DF937A15751C1A96E9C8B63 Jennifer 8. Lee, ''A Season of More'', New York Times, December 24, 2008]</ref>
The atmosphere of religious liberalism and tolerance in the United States has offered American Jews the opportunity to enjoy the holiday period.<ref name="JTA2009" /><ref name=Tracy>[https://newrepublic.com/article/115997/christmas-jews-greatest-holiday Marc Tracy, ''Christmas is the Greatest Jewish Holiday'', The New Republic, December 19, 2013]</ref>
At the same time, many [[American Jews]] do not engage in the same family-gathering activities on the Christmas holiday that Christians in the United States do.<ref name=Tracy /><ref name="TimesDeciding">[https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/16/garden/deciding-to-celebrate-christmas-or-not.html?pagewanted=all Brenda Lane Richardson, ''Deciding to Celebrate Christmas, or Not'', New York Times, December 16, 1987]</ref><ref name="TimesOff">[https://www.nytimes.com/2003/12/22/nyregion/off-on-yom-kippur-it-s-probably-time-to-work-a-holiday.html?pagewanted=all Daniel J. Wakin, ''Off on Yom Kippur? It's Probably Time To Work a Holiday'', New York Times, December 22, 2003]</ref>
===Social=== With [[Christmas Day]] a [[work holiday]] throughout the United States, there is a space of unfilled free time during which much of American commerce and society is not functioning, and which could lead to a sense of alienation or loneliness for American Jews.<ref name="AP2006" /><ref name=Tracy /><ref name=Hwang /><ref name=Lewis /><ref name=ChinaDaily /><ref name=Vigoda>Arlene Vigoda, ''Cry No More'', USA Today, December 13, 1993</ref>
Typical contemporary activities were usually limited to "Chinese and a movie"<ref name=Karch>[http://archive.wired.com/geekmom/2012/12/happy-chinese-and-a-movie/ Marziah Karch, ''Happy Chinese and a Movie'', Wired, December 24, 2014]</ref><ref name=Wiener>[http://www.jta.org/2013/12/24/news-opinion/the-telegraph/the-joy-of-not-celebrating-christmas Julie Wiener, ''The joy of not celebrating Christmas'', JTA (Jewish Telegraphic Agency), December 24, 2013]</ref><ref name=Vozick>[http://popwatch.ew.com/2009/12/25/christmas-chinese-food-movies/ Simon Vozick-Levinson, ''Chinese food and movies: A Christmas tradition'', Entertainment Weekly, December 25, 2009]</ref>—consuming a meal at a [[Chinese restaurant]], which tend to be open for business on the Christmas holiday, and watching a movie at the theater or at home, stereotypically a rerun of ''[[It's a Wonderful Life]]''.<ref name=ChinaDaily /><ref name=Heyman2010>[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204527804576043883500181362 Marshall Heyman, '' 'Tis the Season For Matzo Balls'', Wall Street Journal, December 27, 2010]</ref><ref name=Duckett>[http://articles.mcall.com/1995-12-18/features/3058216_1_christmas-eve-single-young-jewish-professionals-jewish-life Jodi Duckett, ''Jewish Singles Mingle Christmas Eve'', Allentown Morning Call, December 18, 1995]</ref><ref name=Gluck>[http://www.jewishjournal.com/culture/article/what_young_jews_do_on_christmas_eve_20111220 Robert Gluck, ''What young Jews do on Christmas Eve'', Los Angeles Jewish Journal, December 20, 2011]</ref><ref name=SLPD />
With the rise of the Matzo Ball and similar local events, the night of December 24 has become an opportunity to transform this otherwise brief period into one made to gather, socialize, catch up with old friends, network, drink, flirt, and romance.<ref name=Tracy /><ref name=Gluck /><ref name="TimesThings">[http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/12/23/things-to-do-if-you-dont-do-christmas/ Jennifer 8. Lee, ''Things to Do if You Don’t Do Christmas'', New York Times, December 23, 2004]</ref><ref name=Davis /> The event has turned Christmas Eve into a matchmaking or dating event for young Jews<ref name="AP2006" /><ref name=Davis /><ref name="JTA2007">[http://jta.org/news/article-print/2007/12/31/106182/matzoball Ben Harris and Jacob Berkman, ''Hitting the Matzo Balls on Christmas Eve'', JTA (Jewish Telegraphic Agency),December 31, 2007] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120527175129/http://www.jta.org/news/article-print/2007/12/31/106182/matzoball |date=May 27, 2012 }}</ref><ref name="Philly">''This Jewish singles party comes but once a year, Christmas Eve has become the hottest annual date for meeting a potential mate'', Philadelphia Inquirer, December 25, 2003, available via [http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_multi=PI|&p_product=PI&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&s_site=philly&s_trackval=PI&s_search_type=keyword&s_dispstring=%22matzoball%22%20AND%20%22christmas%20eve%22%20AND%20date%28all%29&p_field_advanced-0=&p_text_advanced-0=%28%22matzoball%22%20AND%20%22christmas%20eve%22%29&xcal_numdocs=20&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&xcal_useweights=no&s_trackval=GooglePM Newsbank Archives]</ref> and "the biggest singles night of the year."<ref name=Hwang /><ref name="Globe">[http://www.boston.com/lifestyle/relationships/articles/2008/12/24/looking_for_a_marry_little_holiday/ Meredith Goldstein, ''Looking for a marry little holiday?'', Boston Globe, December 24, 2008]</ref> The event is an opportunity to meet "'a lot of like-minded people dressed up to have a good time, network, find their mate'."<ref name=Vilensky />
Whether "by their own volition or by the insistent nudging of their parents and grandparents," many young American Jews now attend these Christmas Eve singles events.<ref name=Heyman2010 /> While some party-goers admit that they attend with an eye toward flirting and romance, others maintain that they go only to spend time with friends, dance, and drink cocktails.<ref name=Vilensky />
Events such as the Matzo Ball are also seen by some leaders in the Jewish community as a last chance to engage some young American Jews who come "out of the woodwork" for drinking and socializing but are otherwise difficult to reach and uninvolved with Jewish organizations.<ref name=Werthheimer>[https://books.google.com/books?id=gH0RuVR24rYC&pg=PA7&dq=%28%22matzo+ball%22+OR+matzoball%29+%22christmas+eve%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=CQyRVPiNJpGqoQTLxoCYAQ&ved=0CEwQ6AEwBzgK#v=onepage&q=%28%22matzo%20ball%22%20OR%20matzoball%29%20%22christmas%20eve%22&f=false Jack Werthheimer, ''The New Jewish Leaders: Reshaping the American Jewish Landscape'', University Press of New England, 2011, p. 7]</ref>
===Event=== The first Matzo Ball event was held in [[Boston]] in 1987 and organized by local social figure Andy Rudnick.<ref name="AP2006" />
As a [[Boston University]] [[senior (education)|senior]] in [[political science]] and part-time bartender in 1986, Rudnick attended a Jewish young professionals Christmas Eve gathering at a local hotel, where he found a staid atmosphere similar to a high school prom, with women on one side of the room, and men on the other.<ref name=Hwang /><ref name=Lewis /><ref name=Heyman2010 /><ref name=Robinson /> The environment, including the strong lighting, waits to purchase drink tickets and to receive a drink, bad music, and stale [[latkes]] were not conductive to meeting people and having fun.<ref name=Kirchick>[http://tabletmag.com/jewish-life-and-religion/187629/matzo-ball-singles James Kirchick, ''Matzoball Memories: My uncle, godfather of the Jewish singles business, created a Christmas Eve tradition'', Tablet Magazine, December 22, 2014]</ref><ref name=Gluck />
Following that incident, Rudnick began developing the idea for hosting an event the next December 24 at the nightclub he then bartended part-time at, Metro.<ref name=Hwang /><ref name=Heyman2010 /><ref name=Robinson /> He and his friends built up awareness of the upcoming event through word of mouth, posters, and flyers hand-distributed, including at malls.<ref name=Kirchick /> Some coverage of the event by local radio DJs, who invited Rudnick on-air to promote it,<ref name=Gluck /> and Rudnick's on-air exaggerations about expected ticket sales,<ref name=Kirchick /> helped spread the word and 2,000 people attended the first Matzo Ball.<ref name=Hwang /><ref name=Lewis /><ref name=Heyman2010 /><ref name=Gluck /> Rudnick soon quit his job in [[commercial real estate]] to focus on the organization and event, and expanding to other cities.<ref name=Lewis /><ref name=Robinson />
The name of the event and the name of the organization were created on-the-spot in 1987. The event name was inspired by Rudnick's [[Irish-American]] coworker's question about Jewish cuisine,<ref name=Kirchick /><ref name=Heyman2010 /> and the organization's name was thought up by Rudnick and his [[Italian-American]] nightclub bosses, Boston Entertainment mogul brothers John and Patrick Lyons, who were concerned about offending both Jews and Christians with the stereotypical name Matzo Ball for an event being held on Christmas Eve, and harming the club's reputation.<ref name=Kirchick /><ref name=Lewis /><ref name=Robinson>[http://www.thejewishweek.com/news/new-york-news/matzoball-founder-launches-matzobowl Heather Robinson, ''MatzoBall Founder Launches 'MatzoBowl''', New York Jewish Week, April 3, 2013]</ref> Other names for the event considered by Rudnick were 'Tribe Trot' and 'Heeb Hop', both of which were rejected upon the recommendation of Rudnick's mother, who also found the name Matzo Ball to be cute.<ref name=Kirchick />
The event has permeated American Jewish consciousness, even winding up in fiction,<ref name=Segre>[https://books.google.com/books?id=KfiT_zp9GRYC&q=%22matzo+ball%22+%22christmas+eve%22&dq=%22matzo+ball%22+%22christmas+eve%22 Francesca Segrè, ''Daughter of the Bride'', 2006, pp. 243–244]</ref><ref name=Liebman>[https://books.google.com/books?id=92i6FhHYthEC&pg=PT32 Shana Liebman, ''Sex, Drugs & Gefilte Fish: The Heeb Storytelling Collection'', Grand Central Publishing, 2009, p. PT32]</ref><ref name=Long>[https://books.google.com/books?id=b5H7Ga-YpO4C&pg=PT8#v=onepage&q&f=false Lance Long, ''Boca Chita'', BENU Books, 2012, p. PT8]</ref> and has been cited as a desired destination in online gossip publications.<ref name=TMZ>[http://www.tmz.com/videos/0_chqi7xeq/ ''Kenny Santucci: I Wanna Go To 'Matzo Ball' '', TMZ.com, December 2014]</ref>
==Events==
===Logistics===
====Tickets and crowd==== Matzo Ball events are generally held at popular nightclubs in the cities in which the event is located.<ref name=Kirchick /><ref name=Lewis /><ref name=Duckett /><ref name=Davis>[https://books.google.com/books?id=KbwfAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA149&dq=%28%22matzo+ball%22+OR+matzoball%29+%22christmas+eve%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=CQyRVPiNJpGqoQTLxoCYAQ&ved=0CFEQ6AEwCDgK#v=onepage&q=%28%22matzo%20ball%22%20OR%20matzoball%29%20%22christmas%20eve%22&f=false Carin Davis, ''Life, Love, Lox: Real-World Advice for the Modern Jewish Girl'', [[Running Press]], 2010, p. 149]</ref><ref name="JTA2007" /> The average age range of the crowd spans from the 20s through 40s, unless otherwise specified.<ref name=Kirchick /><ref name=Hwang /><ref name=Heyman2010 /><ref name=Duckett /><ref name=Rourke /> A ticket purchased at the door can cost $30–40.<ref name=Heyman2010 /><ref name=Vilensky /><ref name=Zeitlin /><ref name=WaPo2013 />
Attendance at the New York event can average from 1,100 to 1,700 people,<ref name=Heyman2010 /><ref name=Heyman2011 /> with an entry line forming outside the venue 30 minutes before the scheduled start time.<ref name=Heyman2010 /> Crowd sizes at smaller venues, like in Boca Raton, can be 800 to 1,000 people.,<ref name=ChinaDaily /> but with a crowd that arrives later, leading to a long line for entry at midnight.<ref name="Heyman2011"/>
The event is typically scheduled to begin at 8 or 9 p.m. and run through the [[last call (bar term)|last call]] time for the state/locality, with peak attendance and flirting at approximately midnight.<ref name=ChinaDaily /><ref name=Heyman2010 /><ref name=SLPD>[https://www.questia.com/newspaper/1P2-32845063/the-matzo-ball-no-it-isn-t-something-to-eat ''The Matzo Ball: No, It Isn't Something to Eat'', St. Louis Post-Dispatch, December 17, 1993, p. 3G]</ref><ref name=WaPo2013 /><ref name=Heyman>[http://thematzoballparty.blogspot.com/2004_04_01_archive.html Stephen Heyman, ''Matzo Ball Offers Singular Senation for Jewish Partyers'', Palm Beach Post, December 26, 2004]</ref><ref name=RobinsonNYB>[http://www.nyblueprint.com/dating/reflections-matzo-ball Heather Robinson, ''Reflections on the matzo ball'', New York Blueprint, December 26, 2013]</ref>
In some cities, ticket prices include hors d'oeuvres and sometimes a ticket for a free drink, sometimes limited to early arrivals.<ref name=Arseniuk>[http://www.digitaleditiononline.com/publication/index.php?i=56606&m=&l=&p=67&pre=&ver=swf Melissa Arseniuk, ''Nightlife: Seven Nights'', Vegas Seven, December 23, 2010, p. 65]</ref><ref name=Pesce>Nicole Lyn Pesce, ''Monday in New York'', New York Daily News, December 24, 2007, p. 30</ref> The crowd is often well-dressed.<ref name=Baicker>[http://www.nbcphiladelphia.com/the-scene/archive/Jewish-at-Christmas.html Sarah Baicker, ''Jewish at Christmas?'', NBC 10 Philadelphia, December 19, 2008]</ref>
====Associated activities==== Some party-goers to Christmas Eve singles events "[[pregaming|pregame]]" with friends at home before arriving at the event.<ref name=Yadegaran>[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-11424305.html Jessica Yadegaran, ''Christmas Eve party alternative: Latke Ball'', Contra Costa Times, December 10, 2007]</ref>
In some cities, the Matzo Ball is linked officially or unofficially to other Jewish events on Christmas Eve and Christmas Day, such as volunteering at local food banks.<ref name=Lewis />
Rudnick and SYJP have also experimented with a variety of other activities, including singles cruises, Valentine's Day and Passover-linked parties, and a magazine.<ref name=Kirchick />
====Co-sponsorship==== The official organizer for the Matzo Ball events is Rudnick's Society of Young Jewish Professionals.<ref name="AP2006" /> An occasional sponsor of the Matzo Ball is JDate, even during those periods when JDate organized its own Christmas Eve event in Los Angeles under the name 'Schmooz-a-Palooza'.<ref name=Heyman2010 /><ref name="Gluck"/><ref name="Heyman2011"/><ref name=Block />
Local groups and individuals also sometimes work with SYJP, especially when the event is new or newly reintroduced in a given city.<ref name=Rourke /><ref name=Thomas /><ref name=PostCourier />
====Crowd diversity==== At various times, the Matzo Ball has experimented with dividing some of its venues by age into different rooms or even separate adjacent venues, even giving a separate event name, "The Big Chill", to the party catering to 30-somethings seeking a less-noisy environment.<ref name=Duckett /><ref name="Heyman2011">[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204464404577117014063912978 Marshall Heyman, ''The Matzo Ball Night Out'', Wall Street Journal, December 24, 2011]</ref><ref name=Block /><ref name=Zibart>[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-981257.html Eve Zibart, ''Matzo Balls on Christmas Eve'', Washington Post, December 24, 1993, p. N13]</ref><ref name=MatzoBall2014 /> The events are open to the public, and couples and non-Jews looking for a Christmas Eve activity are welcome to come,<ref name=Hwang /><ref name=ChinaDaily /><ref name=Block>[http://blogs.miaminewtimes.com/cultist/2011/12/matzoballin_a_christmas_eve_ba.php Tracy Block, ''Matzo Ballin': A Christmas Eve Bash for the Chosen People'', Miami New Times, December 22, 2011]</ref> "though, obviously, it caters largely to young people who aren't spending Christmas Eve with their families or at church."<ref name=Vilensky>[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304483804579280720216837300 Mike Vilensky, ''Another Kind of Christmas Eve Tradition: The Matzo Ball Brings 'Young Professionals, Jewish Singles' Together'', Wall Street Journal, December 25, 2013]</ref>
In some Matzo Ball cities, a number of attendees are from out-of-town, particularly in cities that have large numbers of visitors or where families tend to gather for the winter holidays, such as Boca Raton, which has a large number of New Yorkers during the holiday period.<ref name="Heyman2011"/>
====Atmosphere==== Rudnick's formula for the Matzo Ball atmosphere is to find a large venue that can handle the large crowds, and for the lights to get dimmer and the music to get louder gradually over the course of the night.<ref name=Rourke /><ref name="JTA2006">[http://www.jta.org/2006/12/27/archive/first-person-the-search-for-the-better-matzo-ball-leads-to-a-tour-of-manhattan-debauch ''First Person: The Search for the Better Matzo Ball Leads to a Tour of Manhattan Debauchery'', JTA (Jewish Telegraphic Agency), December 27, 2006]</ref> This allows for easier mingling and conversation earlier in the night before the hip-hop and dance/house music becomes loud enough to encourage dancing.<ref name=Hwang /><ref name=JTA2006 /><ref name=Schoeneman>Deborah Schoeneman, ''Have a Ball with Matzo or Monster's'', New York Post, December 20, 2001</ref>
Rudnick rejects the usual aspects of Jewish social events, including name tags, announcements, and live bands, because they would be a distraction from mingling.<ref name=Kirchick /><ref name=Rourke />
===Locations=== Rudnick and SYJP expand the Matzo Ball to new cities when they believe that have found the infrastructure and potential clientele of young, upscale Jewish people necessary to make the event successful.<ref name=Rourke />

Prior to the mid-2000s, in [[Los Angeles]], the Matzo Ball had ceded the region to the much more locally long-standing [[#Schmooz-a-Palooza|Schmooz-a-Palooza]] hosted by Stu & Lew Productions<ref name="AP2006" /> (which was acquired by [[JDate]] in 2006<ref name="Schmooz">[http://www.onlinedatingscene.com/archives/214 Press Release, ''Spark Networks Acquires Schmooz-a-Palooza'', OnlineDatingScene, December 7, 2006]</ref>), before becoming a co-promoter for the event with JDate.<ref name="MatzoBall" /> Starting at least as early as 2009, the Matzo Ball partnered with JDate and promoted as a Matzo Ball the JDate/Stu & Lew Productions Schmooz-a-Palooza.<ref name="MatzoBall" /> By 2014, the Schmooz-a-Palooza brand appeared to have been retired from use.<ref name=Schmooz2014 />
===Results=== Rudnick promotes the in-person meetings that take place at the Matzo Ball as an antidote to online dating and its tendency to urge daters to always look for an even better catch around the corner.<ref name=Robinson />
The socializing and flirting that takes place at the Matzo Ball gives rise to many romantic relationships.<ref name=Hwang /> The organizers believe that more than 1,000 marriages have resulted from meetings at various Matzo Balls (and stopped counting after reaching the 1,000 mark<ref name=Heyman2010 />), and Rudnick himself met his wife at a Matzo Ball in 1997, where she tended bar.<ref name="AP2006" /><ref name=Kirchick /><ref name=Robinson /><ref name="Boca">''Plans Under Way for holiday 'Matzo Ball' in Boca, Elsewhere'', Boca Raton/Delray Beach News, November 4, 2007, p. 6A, available via [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1291&dat=20071104&id=jQcQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=GY8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=5479,152635 Google News]</ref>
As of the mid-2010s, there is now a "second generation" of Matzo Ball attendees — children born to parents who first met at the Matzo Ball in previous decades — who are now old enough to attend.<ref name=Lewis />
==Competitors== There are also a number of competitors to the Matzo Ball and other events organized in cities where no Matzo Ball is held.<ref name="AP2006" /><ref name="JTA2007" />
The competition among the Christmas Eve parties has occasionally been stiff, especially during the "Matzo Ball wars of the early 90s", with use of similar-sounding event names, the use of [[touts]] and [[bouncer (doorman)|bouncers]] to chase away those touts outside events, and ticket dumping to "crush" the competition.<ref name=Kirchick />
===The Ball=== A major competitor to the Matzo Ball in New York is known simply as "The Ball",<ref name="AP2006" /> which began operations in 1994.<ref name="Heyman2011"/> In New York City, The Ball focuses on having separate venues, five as of the early 2010, targeted by age [[demographic]], and with attendees receiving limousine service between venues,<ref name="JTA2007" /><ref name="JTA1999">[http://jta.org/news/article/1999/11/30/14809/Thesearchfortheb ''Seeking the perfect Matzo Ball'', JTA (Jewish Telegraphic Agency), November 30, 1999] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101218214925/http://jta.org/news/article/1999/11/30/14809/Thesearchfortheb |date=December 18, 2010 }}</ref> although party-goers must purchase an all-access pass to attend all five events.<ref name=Heyman2011 />
In 2008, the organizer of The Ball, LetMyPeopleGo, attempted to expand the event into 24 other cities with significant Jewish populations.<ref name="CBDYAG2008">[http://cbdyag.wordpress.com/2008/12/12/move-over-latke-ball-the-ball-2008-is-in-town 'challahbackgirl', ''Move over Latke Ball, The Ball 2008 is in Town'', Jews' Next Dor, December 12, 2008], archived at [https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fcbdyag.wordpress.com%2F2008%2F12%2F12%2Fmove-over-latke-ball-the-ball-2008-is-in-town&date=2010-06-22 WebCitation.org]</ref><ref name="EventBrite2008">[http://theballhardrock.eventbrite.com/ Press Release, ''The Ball 2008 in Ft Lauderdale- The Nation's Biggest Jewish Singles Event (Christmas Eve, December 24)'', EventBrite.com, 2008], archived at [https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Ftheballhardrock.eventbrite.com%2F&date=2010-06-22 WebCitation.org]</ref> In almost all of those cities, with local marketing and co-hosting of the event performed by JDate,<ref name="DCistOrig" /> it was cancelled near the event date.<ref name="CBDYAG2008" /><ref name="DCistOrig" /><ref name="WaPo2007">[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/12/19/AR2007121901932_pf.html Fritz Hahn, Rhome Anderson and David Malitz, ''Nightlife Agenda'', Washington Post, December 20, 2007] ("Correction to This Article: The Ball, originally listed under Dec. 25, has been cancelled.")</ref>
However, the Los Angeles version of The Ball, which was instead co-sponsored and co-marketed by the young adults divisions of the LA Guardians, the [[Los Angeles Jewish Home for the Aging]] foundation, was successful and held again in 2009.<ref name="HuffPo2009">[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/julie-spira/jewish-singles-gather-in_b_403698.html Julie Spira, ''Jewish Singles Gather in LA to Celebrate the Holidays in Style and Support the Elderly'', Huffington Post, December 28, 2009]</ref><ref name="NBCLA2009">[http://www.nbclosangeles.com/around-town/events/Mix-and-Be-Merry-at-The-Ball-79985352.html Alysia Gray Painter, ''Mix and Be Merry at The Ball: Jewish singles hobnob in Hollywood on December 24th'', NBC Los Angeles, December 23, 2009]</ref><ref name="Guardians2009">[http://www.laguardians.com/magazines/winter_09.pdf ''Young Divisions' Holiday Ball'', The Guardian (newsletter), Winter 2009, p. 10]</ref> The co-sponsorship continued, raising money for the LA Jewish Home, through 2012.<ref name=PRWeb>[http://www.prweb.com/releases/jewishsingles/ball/prweb10223786.htm Jeff Strank, Press Release, ''Christmas Eve Not a Silent Night for 4,000 Jewish Singles at "The Ball"'', PRWEb.com, December 12, 2012]</ref> In 2013, the Guardians and The Ball broke off their association, as the Guardians began organizing their own Christmas Eve event.<ref name=Donney>[http://www.jewishjournal.com/calendar_stories/article/calendar_december_21_january_3 Laura Donney, ''Calendar: December 21-January 3'', Los Angeles Jewish Journal, December 19, 2013]</ref> The Ball, in turn, partnered nationally with online dating sites [[Match.com]] and [[OKCupid]], both of which advertised The Ball events across the country to their members.<ref name=Zeitlin>[http://www.thejewishweek.com/news/short-takes/o-holy-night Alan Zeitlin, ''O Holy Night!: Christmas Eve is abrim with lots 'o Matzo Balls and other events designed with Jewish singles in mind'', New York Jewish Week, December 23, 2013]</ref>
As of 2014, The Ball held Christmas Eve events in two cities: Los Angeles and New York.<ref name=TheBall2014>[http://www.letmypeoplego.com/?noredirect=1 ''Jewish Singles'', Let My People Go, 2014]</ref>
===Niche and local events===
====New York City==== Other New York City Jewish Christmas Eve events include parties for "the pro-Israel crowd, Jewish gays and lesbians, and downtown Jewish hipsters."<ref name="JTA2007" />
The sheer number of events, combined with the compactness of Manhattan, means that events are often held within a short walking distance, if not eyesight of one another.<ref name="JTA2006" /><ref name="JTA1999" />
====Chicago==== Likewise, by the late 2000s, Chicago Jewish Christmas Eve events ran the gamut of tastes and preferred crowd.<ref name=Riley>[http://www.nbcchicago.com/the-scene/events/Tonight-Eve-of-Christmas-Eve-le-colonial-pasha-subterranean-112381579.html Marcus Riley, ''Tonight: Eve of Christmas Eve'', NBC 5 Chicago, December 23, 2010]</ref> These included gatherings named 'Rockmitzvah', 'Hubukkah', the 'Heebonism' bash (sponsored by [[Heeb Magazine]]), and the more mainstream 'The Juju Ball' and 'Retro Eve', a long running but now defunct event.<ref name=Riley /><ref name="Chicago">[http://www.chicagomag.com/Radar/Nightspotting/December-2008/Matzo-Tov/ Sarah Preston, ''Matzo Tov!'', Chicago Magazine blog, December 11, 2008]</ref>
====Washington, DC==== In Washington, DC, a longtime competitor and alternative to the Matzo Ball has been the Gefilte Fish Gala, an event with no admission charge but only a requested donation, which is usually also held on Christmas Eve unless the night of the 24th coincides with Friday night, the Jewish sabbath.<ref name=Jain>Aruna Jain, (December 23, 2004) [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A18057-2004Dec21.html For Those of Other Faiths, a Not-So-Silent Night] [[Washington Post]]</ref>
Beginning in 2010, an informal group of Washington, DC, Jewish young professionals decided to organize another competitor to the Matzo Ball, the Falafel Frenzy, with all proceeds going to charity.<ref name=WJW2013>[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-2876101191.html Emily Jacobs, ''Falafel Frenzy'', Washington Jewish Week, January 3, 2013]</ref> The event has been successful in collecting money for local charities and continues to be held.<ref name=WaPo2013>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/goingoutguide/for-christmas-week-theres-matzo-ball-and-falafel-frenzy-and-post-holiday-parties/2013/12/23/0bb39598-6c17-11e3-aecc-85cb037b7236_story.html Fritz Hahn and Rhome Anderson, ''For Christmas week, there's Matzo Ball and Falafel Frenzy and post-holiday parties'', Washington Post, December 23, 2013]</ref><ref name=WJW2013 />
====Atlanta==== Atlanta, which had previously hosted an annual "Matzah Ball" unrelated to the SYJP event,<ref name="AJC2006" /> has been the home of competing events for both mainstream audiences, such as the 'Bagel Bash',<ref name="AJC2005">''SCENE: MUSIC / PARTY / CHARITY'', Atlanta Journal-Constitution, December 29, 2005, p. P24, available via [http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=AT&p_theme=at&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=10ECE8761B6E2010&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM NewsBank]</ref><ref name="AJC2004">''SCENE: NIGHTWATCH: Bagel Bash to tell hole story at Tavern'', Atlanta Journal-Constitution, December 23, 2004, p. P24, available via [http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=AT&p_theme=at&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=1072A09CD4E7C254&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM NewsBank]</ref> and niche groups, such as the local [[NCJW]] section's 'Santa Klutz Ball' for older singles.<ref name="JGA">[http://jewishgeorgian.com/JGANovDec09.pdf Jonathan Barach, ''Thought You’d Like to Know'', The Jewish Georgian, November-December 2009, p. 9]</ref>
====Houston==== For a number of years, the Houston JCC sponsored that city's annual 'Bagel Ball' Christmas Eve party,<ref name=Alvarez>[http://www.houstonpress.com/2008-12-18/calendar/the-annual-jewish-community-center-bagel-ball/full/ Olivia Flores Alvarez, ''The Annual Jewish Community Center Bagel Ball'', Houston Press, December 18, 2014]</ref> which is now run independently.<ref name=BagelBall2014>[http://allevents.in/houston/5th-annual-holiday-party-bagel-ball-2014/1509776505968724# ''5th Annual Holiday Party (Bagel Ball 2014)'', AllEvents, 2014]</ref>
===Heeb Magazine 'Heebonism' events=== Heeb Magazine sponsored and organized its 'Heebonism' events in various U.S. cities on Christmas Eve, targeted toward a "hip" audience seeking an alternative to events like the Matzo Ball, beginning in the late 2000s.<ref name=JTA2009 /><ref name=Chicago /><ref name=DenverPost2011>[http://www.denverpost.com/ci_19596055 ''Holiday parties offer something for everyone — from "Heebonism" to "Mistletoe Madness"'', Denver Post, December 23, 2011]</ref> By 2009, Heebonism had expanded to five cities nationally.<ref name=JTA2009 /> Nationally, Heebonism organizers sought to offer a more "culturally substantive" and non-conformist event, with activities including "strip dreidel", video games, and light food.<ref name=JTA2009 /><ref name=DenverPost2011 /> At the Los Angeles/[[Palm Springs]] Heebonism in 2009, strip dreidel was led by [[porn star]]s [[James Deen]] and [[Joanna Angel]].<ref name=LAWeekly>[http://blogs.laweekly.com/westcoastsound/2009/12/last_night_strip_dreidel_chris.php Jeff Weiss, ''Last Night: Strip Dreidel, Christmas Eve Heebonism and Jewjitsu in Palm Springs'', LA Weekly, December 28, 2009]</ref> In Denver, the local Heebonism event had its origin as a private [[pregaming|pre-party]] for those seeking alternative entertainment before heading to the Matzo Ball.<ref name=Rab>[http://blogs.westword.com/latestword/2008/12/heebonism_how_denver_jews_do_c.php Lisa Rab, ''How Jews Do Christmas'', Westword, December 12, 2008]</ref> By 2013, Heebonism had retrenched and Heebonism events outside of Denver apparently had been eliminated.
===Jewish community organized events=== Other major cities have homegrown and well-attended Christmas Eve events that were established long before the Matzo Ball or The Ball entered the local scene.
====Federation YAD/YLD==== These include [[Seattle]]'s Latkepalooza,<ref name="Seattle">[http://blog.seattlepi.com/thebigblog/archives/128291.asp Candace Heckman, ''What if you're Jewish and bored stiff on Christmas Eve?'', Seattle Post-Intelligencer - The Big Blog, December 24, 2007]</ref> [[Cincinnati]]'s Latkapalooza<ref name=AI>[http://americanisraelite.com/archives/29577 Latkapalooza, The American Israelite, January 1, 2014] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20141220054846/http://americanisraelite.com/archives/29577 |date=December 20, 2014 }}</ref> [[San Francisco]]'s The Latke Ball,<ref name="SF">[http://www.jewishjournal.com/thecalendargirls/item/one_jews_christmas_eve/ Jay Firestone, ''One Jew's Christmas Eve'', The Jewish Journal (Los Angeles) - Calendar Girls blog, December 28, 2007]</ref> [[Tampa, Florida|Tampa's]] Vodka Latke,<ref name="AP2006" /> [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix's]] Mazelpalooza,<ref name=Hwang>[http://www.azcentral.com/story/entertainment/events/2014/12/18/mazelpalooza-matzoball/20564363/ Kellie Hwang, ''Dec. 24 is time to party at Mazelpalooza, Matzoball'', Arizona Republic/AZCentral.com, December 18, 2014]</ref><ref name="AZ">[http://www.jewishaz.com/issues/081121/yjpside.html Leisah Woldoff, ''Mazelpalooza rolls out red carpet for YJP'', Jewish News of Greater Phoenix, November 21, 2008]</ref> Dallas's Matzah Ball,<ref name=Blair>[http://blogs.dallasobserver.com/mixmaster/2011/12/the_master_list_the_best_thing_28.php Elizabeth Blair, ''The Master List: The Best Things to Do in Dallas This Holiday Weekend'', Dallas Observer, December 23, 2011]</ref><ref name=JCCDallas>[http://asoft8145.accrisoft.com/jccdallas/index.php?src=gendocs&ref=Matzoh+Ball+2015 ''The Matzah Ball'', Jewish Community Center of Dallas, 2014]</ref> and Austin's Mazel Ball,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.shalomaustin.org/yad|title=YAD: Young Adult Division - Shalom Austin|website=www.shalomaustin.org|access-date=2016-12-05}}</ref> all of which are sponsored by their respective [[Jewish Federation]]'s [[young professional]]s division.
====Jewish Community Centers/Hillels/FIDF==== Christmas Eve events run by local Jewish Community Centers, typically by their young adults division, include Chicago's Matzo Bash (in conjunction with [[Birthright Israel|Taglit - Birthright Israel]], [[Friends of the Israel Defense Forces|FIDF]], and other groups),<ref name=Nelson>[http://articles.redeyechicago.com/2013-12-13/news/45170642_1_holiday-party-holiday-music-dec Samantha Nelson, 8 Holiday Parties, Chicago RedEye, December 13, 2013]</ref><ref name=Friduss>Kevin Friduss, The Official Matzo Bash 2013 in Chicago!, Examiner.com, November 5, 2013</ref> Orland's Twelve24,<ref name=Heritage>[http://www.heritagefl.com/story/2013/12/20/news/twelve24-orlandos-jewish-party-of-the-year/1894.html ''Twelve24: Orlando's Jewish party of the year'', Heritage Florida Jewish News, December 20, 2013]</ref> Dallas's Matzah Ball (in conjunction with the local Federation young adults division),<ref name=Blair /><ref name=JCCDallas /> and Las Vegas's 'Light it Up' (previously ran for 17 years as the Bagel Ball).<ref name=Arseniuk /><ref name=LVRJ2011>[http://www.reviewjournal.com/life/religion/religion-notes-61 Religion Notes, Las Vegas Review Journal, December 17, 2011]</ref><ref name=Lax>[https://books.google.com/books?id=chzQ_-PEwhYC&pg=PT119&dq=%28%22matzo+ball%22+OR+matzoball%29+%22christmas+eve%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=yAuRVKbVEcX3oATxloD4Bg&ved=0CD8Q6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=%28%22matzo%20ball%22%20OR%20matzoball%29%20%22christmas%20eve%22&f=false Rick Lax, ''I Get Paid for This: Kicking Ass and Taking Notes in Vegas'', Huntington Press, 2011, p. PT 119]</ref><ref name=JCCSN>[http://jccsn.org/index.php//events/2014/12/bagel-ball/''Light it Up (Formerly the Bagel Ball)'', JCC of Southern Nevada, 2014]</ref>
Cleveland's local [[Hillel: The Foundation for Jewish Campus Life|Hillel]] young professionals group co-sponsors with FIDF the annual Wrap Up Bash.<ref name=Cleveland>[http://www.clevelandjewishnews.com/news/local/article_48efd16a-86dd-11e4-b060-57bbc7250390.html ''Friends of the IDF, JCLE to host Wrap Up Bash'', Cleveland Jewish News, December 18, 2014]</ref>
===Schmooz-a-Palooza=== Schmooz-a-Palooza was the long-running Los Angeles counterpart to the Matzo Ball, and was held for the 20th straight year in 2013.<ref name="AP2006" /><ref name=NBCLA>[http://www.nbclosangeles.com/entertainment/the-scene/Social-and-Seasonal-Schmooz-a-Palooza-236745831.html Alysia Gray Painter, ''Social and Seasonal: Schmooz-a-Palooza: Jewish singles will gather at Red O for a festive mixer of glammed-out proportions'', NBC 4, December 20, 2013]</ref><ref name="JDateSchmooz">[http://static.jdate.com/events/schmooz-a-palooza JDate's 16th Annual Schmooz-A-Palooza, JDate.com (2009)]</ref> It originated with Stu & Lew Productions, which was acquired by [[JDate]] in 2006.<ref name="Schmooz" /> The event evolved over the years from a [[social mixer]] to a party atmosphere, bringing together, for example, southern Californians who had not seen each other since their younger years in Jewish communal settings.<ref name="Journal2003">[http://www.jewishjournal.com/up_front/article/have_a_holly_jolly_schmoozfest_20031219 Keren Engelberg, ''Have a Holly Jolly Schmooz-fest'', Jewish Journal (Los Angeles), December 18, 2003]</ref> It was also a noted opportunity for reconnecting and romance.<ref name="Metromix">[http://losangeles.metromix.com/events/article/your-week-on-a/271538/content Alie Ward, ''Your week, on a platter: Dec. 24-30 brings you horny Jews and Hamburger combovers'', Metromix.com, December 24, 2007]</ref>
By the late 2000s and early 2010s, Schmooz-a-Palooza had become integrated into the Matzo Ball network of nationwide events<ref name="MatzoBall" /><ref name=MatzoBall2013 /> and faced competition from other local events, including a [[#The Ball|local young Jewish professionals charitable group's]] directly competing mixer and a Jewish comedy night at the [[Laugh Factory]],<ref name=Journal2013>[http://www.jewishjournal.com/calendar_stories-/article/calendar_december_21_january_3 Calendar: December 21 - January 3, The Jewish Journal, December 19, 2013]</ref> along with more loosely organized events, such as music performances by Jewish musicians and informal socializing and drinking organized by local [[Moishe House]]s.<ref name=JewishJournal2011>[http://www.jewishjournal.com/picks_clicks/article/chanukah_events_around_los_angeles_20111218 Ryan Torok, ''Chanukah events around Los Angeles'', Los Angeles Jewish Journal, December 18, 2011]</ref>
By 2014, the Stu & Lew Productions and 'Schmooz-a-Palooza' brands appeared to no longer be in use for Christmas Eve parties and to have been retired.<ref name=Schmooz2014>[http://jdate.com/schmooz/ Schmooz-A-Palooza, 2014 (last modified November 25, 2013)]</ref>
==Similarly named events unaffiliated with SYJP==
===Other Christmas Eve singles events=== Prior to Rudnick's organizing of the Matzo Ball in Boston in 1987 and expansion into other cities, Jewish organizations in other cities had used similar names for their own Christmas Eve singles events.
The [[Jewish Community Center]] of [[Dallas]] organizes its annual "Matzoh Ball" or "Matzah Ball" event, having begun in either 1981<ref name="NewsBank1981">''Get Out There!'', The Dallas Morning News, December 22, 2008, available via [https://news.google.com/archivesearch?q=%22The+29th+annual+Matzoh+Ball%22 Google News Archives/NewsBank]</ref> or 1984.<ref name="NewsBank84">''Weekly Planner'', The Dallas Morning News, December 15, 2001, available via [https://news.google.com/archivesearch?q=%22The+17th+annual+party+for+Jewish+singles%22 Google News Archives/NewsBank]</ref> The event continues to be run each Christmas Eve under that name, now jointly organized by the JCC of Dallas and the local Jewish Federation young adults division,<ref name="Blair"/><ref name="JCCDallas"/><ref name="Observer">[http://www.dallasobserver.com/2009-12-24/calendar/kosher-kisses Katey Margolis, ''Kosher Kisses'', Dallas Observer, December 23, 2009]</ref> and is unaffiliated with the Matzo Ball event and Rudnick.<ref name="MatzoBall" />
Atlanta also had its own "Matzah Ball" for many years.<ref name="AJC2006">''Detours: Alterna-thrills'', Atlanta Journal-Constitution, February 9, 2006, p. 28, available via [https://news.google.com/archivesearch?q=atlanta+%22matzah+ball%22+&scoring=a&hl=en&ned=us&sa=N&sugg=d&as_ldate=2006&as_hdate=2007&lnav=hist8 Google News/NewsBank]</ref>
An identically named Matzoball event has been held on Christmas Eve in Toronto since 1988.<ref name=Koren>[http://www.shalomlife.com/news/21339/matzoball-2013-a-quarter-century-of-jews-partying-together-on-xmas-giveaway/?ModPagespeed=noscript Daniel Koren, ''Matzoball 2013: A Quarter Century of Jews Partying Together on Xmas'', Shalom Life, December 17, 2013.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131222005341/http://www.shalomlife.com/news/21339/matzoball-2013-a-quarter-century-of-jews-partying-together-on-xmas-giveaway/?ModPagespeed=noscript |date=December 22, 2013 }}</ref> As of 2013, it is sponsored by the Canadian unit of the [[Jewish National Fund]] and organized by Magen Boys Entertainment.<ref name=Koren /> The event organizers have indicated their desire to expand to other cities in Canada, particularly Montreal and Vancouver, in future years.<ref name=Koren />
====SYJP trademark disputes over Matzo Ball name==== Rudnick and SYJP have also come into conflict with organizers of other events named similarly to Matzo Ball,<ref name=Kirchick /> including Seattle's Jewish Federation young leadership division, which changed it event name from Matzah Ball to Latkapalooza in 2004 after receiving a [[cease-and-desist]] letter from Rudnik's attorneys.<ref name=Rosenstein>[http://jewishsound.org/the-battle-over-a-name/ Joshua Rosenstein, ''The battle over a name'', The Jewish Sound, December 18, 2004]</ref> The Federation's attorney's insisted that because of the lapse in SYJP's federal trademark registration for the term in the late 1990s, and because the Federation had been using the term locally during that period, they were entitled to continue to do so.<ref name=Rosenstein />
===Bowling-related events=== The [[Jewish Federation]] of [[Greater Los Angeles area|Greater Los Angeles]] entertainment division organized a late spring "Matzah Bowl" event for a number of years, beginning in 1996.<ref name="LABowl">[http://www.jewishjournal.com/calendar_stories/article/calendar_singles_20010511/ Mike Levy, ''Calendar'', (Los Angeles) Jewish Journal, May 10, 2001]</ref> In Atlanta, the promoter of the 'Bagel Bash' organized an early spring bowling function for singles called the "Matzah Bowl". A 2009 Christmas Eve musical event at [[Brooklyn Bowl]], co-sponsored by Israel's New York [[Consulate General]], was dubbed "The Matzah Bowl".<ref name="NYTBowl">[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/24/urbaneye/24ubn3.html ''And To All a Good Night'', New York Times, December 23, 2009]</ref><ref name="Brooklyn">[http://www.brooklynbowl.com/event-detail/?id=2881 ''Brooklyn Bowl's First Annual Matzah Bowl! - Inaugural Tribal Music Festival'', Brooklyn Bowl, 2009] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091212111909/http://www.brooklynbowl.com/event-detail/?id=2881 |date=2009-12-12 }}</ref> The event derived its name in part from its location in a Brooklyn bowling alley.
===Other events not targeted at single adults=== Smaller Jewish community entities have also used variations on the "Matzo Bowl" name for a variety of events, including for knowledge competitions held by individual synagogues<ref name="TBT">[http://www.templebethtorahli.org/tbttimes-06-08.pdf Steve Dershowitz, ''From the Prexy's Computer'', in Temple Beth Torah Times, June 2008] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081123033155/http://www.templebethtorahli.org/tbttimes-06-08.pdf |date=2008-11-23 }}</ref> and fundraising events organized by chapters of [[Alpha Epsilon Pi]].<ref name="Greek">[http://www.greekchat.com/gcforums/archive/index.php/t-9966.html KSUViolet06, ''What's your big thing(s)?'', GreekChat.com, August 15, 2004]</ref>
The [[Greater Kansas City]] Council of [[BBYO]] and its [[Aleph Zadik Aleph|AZA]] [[Max Nordau|Nordaunian]] chapter sponsor a large annual teen dance called the Matzo Ball, which celebrated its 75th anniversary in April 2010.<ref name="KCS2004">Kansas City Star, March 31, 2004, p. 24, available via [http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=KC&p_theme=kc&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=101AB40AE39E4DAB&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM NewsBank]</ref><ref name="KCJC2010">[http://www.kcjc.com/201004029169/news/nordaunian-aza-alumni-plan-reunion-alongside-matzo-ball.html Rick Hellman, ''Nordaunian AZA alumni plan reunion alongside Matzo Ball'', Kansas City Jewish Chronicle, April 2, 2010] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100409071158/http://www.kcjc.com/201004029169/news/nordaunian-aza-alumni-plan-reunion-alongside-matzo-ball.html |date=April 9, 2010 }}</ref>
==Criticisms== The Matzo Ball and similar events have been subject to mild criticism that the events are "[[meet markets]]"<ref name="JTA2009" /> or, more punningly, "[kosher] meat markets."<ref name="DCistOrig">[http://dcist.com/2008/12/22/good_to_be_a_jew_on_christmas.php Josh Novikoff, ''Hooking up This Hanukkah?'', DCist.com, December 22, 2008] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090314051242/http://dcist.com/2008/12/22/good_to_be_a_jew_on_christmas.php |date=March 14, 2009 }}</ref><ref name=Winn>Amy Winn, ''Find Fun at Place on 'Fring of Christmas' '', Atlanta Journal-Constitution, December 23, 2002, p. 1E</ref> Women attendees tend to dress inappropriately in a revealing manner while men at the event are liable to use awkward pickup lines and noticeably prowl.<ref name=Davis /><ref name=RobinsonNYB />
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://www.matzoball.org/ Matzo Ball official website] *[http://www.letmypeoplego.com The Ball official website] *[http://www.mazelpalooza.com Phoenix Mazelpalooza 2014] *[http://www.jewishfed.org/news/events/latke-ball-2014 San Francisco Latke Ball 2014] *[http://www.jewishtampa.com/community-calendar/vodka-latke-2014 Tampa Vodka Latke 2014] *[http://www.eventbrite.com/e/the-guardians-present-1224-bourbon-street-at-greystone-manor-tickets-9644780799 Los Angeles Guardians "12.24" 2014] *[http://jewishcincinnati.org/calendar/community-calendar/latkapalooza Cincinnati Latkapalooza 2014] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20141220013305/http://www.jewishinseattle.org/news-events/events/latkepalooza-2013 Seattle Latkepalooza 2013] *[http://matzobash.com/ Chicago Matzo Bash 2014] *[http://www.stuandlew.com/ Stu and Lew Productions presents Schmooz-a-Palooza] and [http://static.jdate.com/events/schmooz-a-palooza/ JDate Events listing for Schmooz-a-Palooza]

The '''National Centre for Knowledge on Men's Violence against Women''' ({{lang-sv|Nationellt centrum för kvinnofrid}}, abbreviated '''NCK''') is a [[Sweden|Swedish]] knowledge and resource centre at [[Uppsala University]], founded in 2006. NCK is working on behalf of the [[Government of Sweden]] to raise awareness at the national level of men's [[violence against women]], and develops new methods for the treatment of abused women. NCK has a mandate to research, educate, compile and spread information. In 2008, its operations expanded to include violence and oppression in the name of honour, and violence in same-sex relationships.<ref>{{cite web|title=Action plan for combating men's violence against women, violence and oppression|url=http://www.regeringen.se/sb/d/9761/a/98653|publisher=The [[Government of Sweden]]|accessdate=20 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Information om Nationellt centrum för kvinnofrid|url=http://www.nck.uu.se/Om_NCK/|publisher=NCK/[[Uppsala University]]|accessdate=20 July 2014|language=Swedish}}</ref><ref name=law-sv>{{cite web|title=Förordning (2006:1072) om nationellt kunskapscentrum för frågor om mäns våld mot kvinnor|url=http://www.riksdagen.se/sv/Dokument-Lagar/Lagar/Svenskforfattningssamling/Forordning-20061072-om-nati_sfs-2006-1072/|publisher=The Swedish Government|accessdate=28 July 2014|language=Swedish}}</ref>
==Organisation== The centre is part of Uppsala University, organised directly under the [[Rector (academia)|rector]], and managed by Professor [[Gun Heimer]].<ref name=Organisation>{{cite web|title=Organisation|url=http://www.nck.uu.se/Om_NCK/Organisation/|publisher=NCK|accessdate=28 July 2014|language=Swedish}}</ref>
==Telephone counseling== Since 2007, the centre have been operating a Government funded national helpline for women who have been subjected to threats and violence ({{lang-sv|Kvinnofridslinjen}}). The [[telephone counseling]] is open 24-hour, toll-free, and the call does not appear on the telephone bill. Staff at the helpline provide support, practical advice, information about the healthcare system and how to report crimes. The staff consist of [[social work]]ers, [[Midwife|midwives]] and [[Nursing|nurses]] with at least five years of professional experience; receiving on average 60 calls a day.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kvinnofridslinjen – national helpline|url=http://www.kvinnofridslinjen.se/index.php?page=startpage|publisher=NCK|accessdate=28 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The Development of a National Helpline for Women subjected to Violence|url=http://nck.uu.se/digitalAssets/49/49512_1nck_kvinnofridslinjen_the_development.pdf|publisher=NCK|accessdate=28 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=National Helpline - Kvinnofridslinjen (020-505050)|url=http://eige.europa.eu/content/national-helpline-kvinnofridslinjen-020505050|publisher=[[European Institute for Gender Equality]]|accessdate=28 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Nyamko Sabuni inviger Kvinnofridslinjen|url=http://www.regeringen.se/sb/d/9722/a/93358|publisher=The Swedish Government|accessdate=28 July 2014|language=Swedish|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808071955/http://www.regeringen.se/sb/d/9722/a/93358|archivedate=8 August 2014|df=}}</ref><ref name="vårdförbundet-sv">{{cite web|title=Mer än 60 samtal om dagen till Kvinnofridslinjen|url=https://www.vardforbundet.se/Vardfokus/Webbnyheter/2012/December/Over-60-samtal-om-dagen-till-Kvinnofridslinjen/|publisher=[[Swedish Association of Health Professionals]]|accessdate=28 July 2014|language=Swedish|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140805052358/https://www.vardforbundet.se/Vardfokus/Webbnyheter/2012/December/Over-60-samtal-om-dagen-till-Kvinnofridslinjen/|archivedate=5 August 2014|df=}}</ref><ref name=interview-sv>{{cite web|title=Socionomen: Ett samtal kan vara avgörande|url=http://kvinnofridslinjen.se/index.php?page=socionomen-ett-samtal-kan-vara-avgoerande|publisher=NCK|accessdate=28 July 2014|language=Swedish}}</ref>

Нишко Народно Позориште |image = Narodno pozoriste Nis.jpg |caption = National Theatre in Niš |address = Sinđelić Square |city = [[Niš]] |country = [[Serbia]] |designation = |latitude = |longitude = |architect = Aleksandar Bugarski |owner = |capacity = 687 |type = |opened = 11 March 1887 as "Sinđelić" Theatre |yearsactive = |rebuilt = 1968, 1986, 2002/03 |closed = |othernames = |production = |currentuse = |website = www.narodnopozoristenis.rs }} The '''National Theatre''' ({{lang-sr|'''Народно позориште у Нишу'''}} or ''{{lang|sr-Latn|'''Narodno Pozorište u Nišu'''}}'') is a theater in [[Serbia]], that was founded in 1887 as [["Sinđelić" Theatre]], and reorganized in 1906 as National Theatre, following the completion of new theatre building. Retrieved 13 May 2013. born 3 April 1964) is a British politician, broadcaster{{cite web |url=http://www.lbc.co.uk/radio/special-shows/phone-farage/ |title=Phone Farage – Special Shows – Radio |publisher=LBC |accessdate=2 March 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170217034459/http://www.lbc.co.uk/radio/special-shows/phone-farage/ |archivedate=17 February 2017 }} and political analyst{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-38695203 |title=Nigel Farage hired by Fox News as a political analyst |publisher=BBC |date=20 January 2017 |accessdate=21 January 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170120222924/http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-38695203 |archivedate=20 January 2017 }}. He has been a [[Member of the European Parliament]] (MEP) for the [[South East England (European Parliament constituency)|South East England]] constituency since 1999 and is a Vice-Chairman of the pro-[[Brexit]] organization [[Leave Means Leave]]. He is best known as the former [[List of UK Independence Party leaders|leader]] of the [[UK Independence Party]] (UKIP) from 2006 to 2009 and again from 2010 to 2016.{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Norman|title=Nigel Farage steps back in at UKIP as Diane James quits|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-37561065|accessdate=5 October 2016|work=BBC News|date=5 October 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170201165038/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-37561065|archivedate=1 February 2017}} He co-chairs the [[Europe of Freedom and Direct Democracy]] (formerly "Europe of Freedom and Democracy") group.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-29692378 |title= UKIP's alliance in Europe rescued by Polish MEP |work= BBC |df= dmy-all }} A prominent [[Euroscepticism in the United Kingdom|Eurosceptic in the UK]], he has been noted for his speeches in the [[European Parliament]],{{cite
