currency. Farage was a founding member of UKIP, having left the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] in 1992 after the signing of the [[Maastricht Treaty]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-20543513 |work=BBC News |title=Profile: Nigel Farage, UKIP leader |last=Goldsmith |first=Rosie |date=4 December 2012 |archivedate=21 September 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921101843/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-20543513 |deadurl=no }} After unsuccessfully campaigning in [[European Parliament|European]] and [[Houses of Parliament|Westminster]] parliamentary elections for UKIP since 1994, he was elected MEP for [[South East England (European Parliament constituency)|South East England]] in the [[European Parliament election, 1999 (United Kingdom)|1999 European Parliament election]]. He was subsequently re-elected in [[European Parliament election, 2004 (United Kingdom)|2004]], [[European Parliament election, 2009 (United Kingdom)|2009]] and, most recently, at the [[European Parliament election, 2014 (United Kingdom)|2014 European parliament election]]. In September 2006, Farage became the [[United Kingdom Independence Party#Leaders of UKIP since 1993|UKIP Leader]] and led the party through the [[European Parliament election, 2009 (United Kingdom)|2009 European Parliament Election]], when it won the second highest share of the popular vote, defeating [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] and the [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrats]] with over two million votes. He stepped down in November 2009 to concentrate on contesting [[Buckingham (UK Parliament constituency)|Buckingham]], the constituency of the [[Speaker of the House of Commons (United Kingdom)|Speaker]], [[John Bercow]], at the [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|2010 general election]], coming third. In November 2010, Farage successfully stood in the [[United Kingdom Independence Party leadership election, 2010|2010 UKIP leadership contest]],{{cite news|last=Sparrow |first=Andrew |date=3 September 2010 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2010/sep/03/nigel-farage-stand-ukip-leadership |title=Nigel Farage to stand for Ukip leadership again |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |archivedate=27 September 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927215740/http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2010/sep/03/nigel-farage-stand-ukip-leadership |deadurl=no }} following the resignation of [[Malcolm Pearson, Baron Pearson of Rannoch|Lord Pearson of Rannoch]]. Farage announced his resignation as leader when he did not win the [[South Thanet (UK Parliament constituency)|South Thanet]] seat in Kent at the [[United Kingdom general election, 2015|2015 general election]], but his resignation was rejected and he remained in his post. In June 2016, Farage was a prominent supporter of the successful campaign for a vote in favour of leaving the EU in [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016|the UK EU membership referendum]].{{cite news|last1=Bennett|first1=Asa|title=Nigel Farage has earned his place in history as the man who led Britain out of the EU|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/06/24/nigel-farage-has-earned-his-place-in-history-as-the-man-who-led/|accessdate=24 June 2016|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=24 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160627065428/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/06/24/nigel-farage-has-earned-his-place-in-history-as-the-man-who-led/|archivedate=27 June 2016}} On 4 July 2016, Farage again announced his resignation as leader of UKIP, triggering a [[UK Independence Party leadership election, September 2016|leadership election]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-36702468|title=UKIP leader Nigel Farage stands down|publisher=BBC News|date=4 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160704092043/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-36702468|archivedate=4 July 2016}} [[Diane James]] was elected to succeed him, but she resigned as leader after just 18 days and Farage became interim leader on 5 October 2016.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-37561065|title=Nigel Farage steps back in at UKIP as Diane James quits|work=BBC news|date=5 October 2016|accessdate=18 October 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170201165038/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-37561065|archivedate=1 February 2017}} A [[UK Independence Party leadership election, November 2016|second leadership election]] was held in November, which was won by [[Paul Nuttall]], who thus succeeded Farage. Telegraph]]|title=The time has come to teach the political class a lesson: I'm back fighting for a real Brexit|date=17 August 2018|last=Farage|first=Nigel}} ==Early life, education and early career== Farage was born in [[Downe]] in [[Kent]], [[England]], the son of Barbara (''née'' Stevens) and Guy Justus Oscar Farage.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-20543513 |last=Goldsmith news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/ukip/10731266/My-six-months-with-normal-Nigel-Farage.html |title=My six months with normal Nigel Farage |first=Martin |last=Durkin |date=30 March 2014 |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140331165432/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/ukip/10731266/My-six-months-with-normal-Nigel-Farage.html |archivedate=31 March 2014 |deadurl=no }}[http://www.ukwhoswho.com/view/article/oupww/whoswho/U15437 'FARAGE, Nigel Paul', ''Who's Who 2012'', A & C Black, 2012; online edn, Oxford University Press, Dec 2011;] online edn, November 2011. Retrieved 22 July 2012. The Farage name comes from a distant [[Huguenot]] ancestor.{{cite news|last=Meltzer |first=Tom |location=London |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/shortcuts/2013/may/10/is-nigel-farage-racist |title=Is Nigel Farage a racist? |work=The Guardian |date=10 May 2013 |accessdate=28 April 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130730113659/http://www.theguardian.com/politics/shortcuts/2013/may/10/is-nigel-farage-racist |archivedate=30 July 2013 |deadurl=no }} One of his great-grandfathers was born to German parents who migrated to London in the 19th century.{{cite news|url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/uk/396897/Great-grandfather-of-Ukip-leader-Nigel-Farage-was-born-to-German-immigrants |title=Great-grandfather of Ukip leader Nigel Farage 'was born to German immigrants' |first=Dion |last=Dassanayake |date=3 May 2013 |newspaper=Daily Express |location=London |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20131031221958/http://www.express.co.uk/news/uk/396897/Great-grandfather-of-Ukip-leader-Nigel-Farage-was-born-to-German-immigrants |archivedate=31 October 2013 |deadurl=no }} His grandfather, Private Harry Farage, fought and was wounded in the [[World War I|First World War]].{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-31771963 |title= Leader profile: 24 hours with Nigel Farage |work= BBC News |date= 4 December 2012 |accessdate= 6 March 2015 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150306170514/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-31771963 |archivedate= 6 March 2015 |df= dmy-all }} His father was a stockbroker who worked in the [[City of London]]. A 2012 [[BBC Radio 4]] profile described Guy Farage as an alcoholic who left the family home when Nigel was five years old. In 1971, Guy Farage gave up alcohol and entered the antiques trade, having lost his Stock Exchange position; the next year, endorsed by friends, he returned to the trading floor at the new Stock Exchange Tower on Threadneedle Street.Flying Free, Nigel Farage, Biteback Publishing, 2011 From 1975 to 1982, Farage was educated at [[Dulwich College]], a fee-paying [[Independent school (United Kingdom)|independent school]] in south London. In his autobiography he pays tribute to the careers advice he received there from England [[Test cricket]]er [[John Dewes]], "who must have spotted that I was quite ballsy, probably good on a platform, unafraid of the limelight, a bit noisy and good at selling things".{{cite news |title=John Dewes obituary |url= http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/opinion/obituaries/article4439440.ece |accessdate=15 May 2015 |work=The Times |location= London |date=14 May 2015}} {{subscription required}} On leaving school in 1982, he decided not to go to university, but to work in the City, trading commodities at the [[London Metal Exchange]]. Initially, he joined the American commodity operation of [[broker]]age firm [[Drexel Burnham Lambert]], transferring to [[Crédit Lyonnais|Crédit Lyonnais Rouse]] in 1986. He joined [[Refco]] in 1994, and [[Natixis|Natexis Metals]] in 2003. ==Political career== ===Early years=== Farage was active in the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] from his school days, having seen a visit to his school by [[Enoch Powell]] and [[Keith Joseph]].{{cite web|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZcmIHT6J0wc|title = Nigel Farage on Absolute Radio: Full Interview|date = 17 April 2015|accessdate = 28 April 2015|website = YouTube|publisher = Google|last = Absolute Radio|authorlink = Absolute Radio|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151019005421/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZcmIHT6J0wc|archivedate = 19 October 2015|df = dmy-all}} In 1981, an English teacher, Chloe Deakin, wrote to the head teacher of Dulwich College, David Emms, asking him to reconsider his decision to appoint Farage as a prefect, citing concerns over Farage's alleged 'fascist' views. Farage later stated that some teachers were hostile to him because he was an admirer of Enoch Powell. Farage said: "Any accusation I was ever involved in far right politics is utterly untrue."{{cite web | url = https://www.channel4.com/news/nigel-farage-ukip-letter-school-concerns-racism-fascism | title = Nigel Farage schooldays letter reveals concerns over fascism | date = 19 September 2013 | website = Channel 4 | publisher = Chennel 4 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170802201628/https://www.channel4.com/news/nigel-farage-ukip-letter-school-concerns-racism-fascism | archivedate = 2 August 2017 | df = dmy-all }} He voted for the [[Green Party (UK)|Green Party]] in [[European Parliament election, 1989 (United Kingdom)|1989]] because of what he saw as their then "sensible" and [[Euroscepticism|Eurosceptic]] policies. He left the Conservatives in 1992 in protest at Prime Minister [[John Major]]'s government's signing of the [[Treaty on European Union]] at [[Maastricht]].{{cite news|title=Profile: Nigel Farage |date=12 September 2006 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/5338364.stm |work=BBC News |accessdate=24 February 2013 |archivedate=19 April 2013 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130419151041/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/politics/5338364.stm |deadurl=no }}{{cite news|title=Question Time: This week's panel |date=28 March 2007 |accessdate=24 February 2013 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/question_time/6499699.stm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070831205129/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/question_time/6499699.stm |archivedate=31 August 2007 |deadurl=no }} He was a founding member of [[UK Independence Party|UKIP]] in 1993. ===European Parliament=== Farage was elected to the [[European Parliament]] in [[European Parliament election, 1999 (United Kingdom)|1999]] and re-elected in [[European Parliament election, 2004 (United Kingdom)|2004]], [[European Parliament election, 2009 (United Kingdom)|2009]] and [[European Parliament election, 2014 (United Kingdom)|2014]]. In 1999 the BBC spent four months filming a documentary about his European election campaign but did not air it. Farage, then head of the UKIP's South East office, asked for a video and had friends make copies which were sold for £5 through the UKIP's magazine. Surrey Trading Standards investigated and Farage admitted the offence.{{cite news|last=Watts |first=Robert |newspaper=[[The Sunday Telegraph]] |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1545162/Making-plans-with-Nigel.html |title=Making plans with Nigel |location=London |date=11 March 2007 |archivedate=6 June 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080606071238/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1545162/Making-plans-with-Nigel.html |deadurl=no }} Farage is presently the leader of the 24-member UKIP contingent in the European Parliament, and co-leader of the multinational Eurosceptic group, [[Europe of Freedom and Direct Democracy]]. Farage was ranked the fifth-most influential MEP by [[Politico]] in 2016, who described him as "one of the two most effective speakers in the chamber".{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.eu/list/the-40-meps-who-actually-matter-european-parliament-mep/nigel-farage/|title=NIGEL FARAGE|date=19 May 2016|language=en-US|access-date=26 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160605033433/http://www.politico.eu/list/the-40-meps-who-actually-matter-european-parliament-mep/nigel-farage/|archivedate=5 June 2016}} ====Jacques Barrot==== On 18 November 2004, Farage announced in the European Parliament that [[Jacques Barrot]], then French Commissioner-designate, had been barred from elected office in France for two years, after being convicted in 2000 of embezzling £2 million from government funds and diverting it into the coffers of his party. He said that French President [[Jacques Chirac]] had granted Barrot amnesty; initial BBC reports said that, under French law, it was perhaps illegal to mention that conviction.{{cite news|url=http://newswww.bbc.net.uk/2/hi/europe/4032113.stm |title=Profile: Jacques Barrot |work=BBC News |date=22 November 2004 |accessdate=8 June 2009 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120529171852/http://newswww.bbc.net.uk/2/hi/europe/4032113.stm |archivedate=29 May 2012 |deadurl=no }} The prohibition in question applies only to French officials in the course of their duties.The prohibition contained in the French penal code against mentioning crimes covered by an amnesty only concerns French officials who may hear of such crimes in the course of their duties (CP L133-11), and does not apply generally (L133-10). The President of the Parliament, [[Josep Borrell]], enjoined him to retract his comments under threat of "legal consequences".{{cite web|url=//www.youtube.com/watch?v=oPLkcgaWc0o|title=MEP Nigel Farage replies to Parliament President Josep Borrell|date=18 November 2004|accessdate=22 November 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130910002624/http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oPLkcgaWc0o|archivedate=10 September 2013}} The following day, it was confirmed that Barrot had received an eight-month suspended jail sentence in the case, and that this had been quickly expunged by the amnesty decided by Chirac and his parliamentary majority. {{cn|date=November 2018}} The Socialist and Liberal groups in the European Parliament then joined forces with UKIP in demanding the resignation of Barrot for failing to disclose the conviction during his confirmation hearings. {{cn|date=November 2018}} ====José Manuel Barroso==== In early 2005, Farage requested that the [[European Commission]] disclose where the individual Commissioners had spent their holidays. The Commission did not provide the information requested, on the basis that the Commissioners had a right of privacy. The German newspaper ''[[Die Welt]]'' reported that the President of the European Commission, [[José Manuel Barroso]], had spent a week on the yacht of the Greek shipping billionaire [[Spiros Latsis]]. It emerged soon afterwards that this had occurred a month before the Commission under Barroso's predecessor [[Romano Prodi]] approved 10.3 million euros of Greek state aid for Latsis's shipping company.{{cite news|url=http://news.independent.co.uk/europe/article223215.ece |title=Barroso survives confidence debate over free holiday with Greek tycoon |location=London |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |date=26 May 2005 |accessdate=8 June 2009 |first=Stephen |last=Castle |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071001091311/http://news.independent.co.uk/europe/article223215.ece |archivedate=1 October 2007 |deadurl=yes }} It also became known that [[Peter Mandelson]], then the British [[EU Commissioner]], had accepted a trip to Jamaica from an unrevealed source. Farage persuaded around 75 [[Member of the European Parliament|MEPs]] from across the political divide to back a motion of no confidence in Barroso, which would be sufficient to compel Barroso to appear before the European Parliament to be questioned on the issue.{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=10000085&sid=aFq2hOeCcYZc&refer=europe |date=25 May 2005 |title=Barroso Fights No-Confidence Vote Amid French Treaty Debate |last=Neuger |first=James G. |work=Bloomberg L.P. |location=New York |accessdate=8 June 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061116065904/http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=10000085&sid=aFq2hOeCcYZc&refer=europe |archivedate=16 November 2006 |deadurl=yes }} The motion was successfully tabled on 12 May 2005, and Barroso appeared before Parliament{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4578261.stm |title=Barroso rebuffs yacht questions |work=BBC News |date=25 May 2005 |accessdate=8 June 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061116065904/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4578261.stm |archivedate=16 November 2006 |deadurl=no }} at a debate on 26 May 2005. The motion was heavily defeated. A Conservative MEP, [[Roger Helmer]], was expelled from his group, the [[European People's Party (European Parliament group)|European People's Party – European Democrats]] (EPP-ED), in the middle of the debate by that group's leader [[Hans-Gert Pöttering]] as a result of his support for Farage's motion. ===UKIP leadership and resignations=== [[File:Nigel Farage of UKIP.jpg|thumb|Farage at the UKIP Conference in 2009]] On 12 September 2006, Farage was [[United Kingdom Independence Party leadership election, 2006|elected leader of UKIP]] with 45 percent of the vote, 20 [[percentage point]]s ahead of his nearest rival.{{cite press release|url=http://www.ukip.org/ukip_news/gen12.php?t=1&id=2526 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061013075242/http://www.ukip.org/ukip_news/gen12.php?t=1&id=2526 |archivedate=13 October 2006 |deadurl=yes |title=Nigel Farage is the new Leader of the UK Independence Party |publisher=UKIP |date=12 September 2006 }} He pledged to bring discipline to the party and to maximise UKIP's representation in local, parliamentary and other elections. In a ''[[PM (Radio 4)|PM]]'' programme interview on [[BBC Radio 4]] that day he pledged to end the public perception of UKIP as a single-issue party and to work with allied politicians in the [[Better Off Out]] campaign, committing himself not to stand against the MPs who have signed up to that campaign.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/6209386.stm |title=UKIP leader 'offered Tory seat' |first=Brian |last=Wheeler |work=BBC News |date=5 December 2006 |accessdate=12 October 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061206231332/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/6209386.stm |archivedate=6 December 2006 }} In his maiden speech to the UKIP conference, on 8 October 2006, Farage told delegates that the party was "at the centre-ground of British public opinion" and the "real voice of opposition". He said: "We've got three [[social democratic]] parties in Britain – Labour, Lib Dem and Conservative are virtually indistinguishable from each other on nearly all the main issues" and "you can't put a cigarette paper between them and that is why there are nine million people who don't vote now in general elections that did back in 1992."{{cite news|title=UKIP 'voice of British majority' |work=BBC News |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/politics/5415252.stm?ls |date=7 October 2006 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130919230637/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/politics/5415252.stm?ls |archivedate=19 September 2013 }} At 10pm on 19 October 2006, Farage took part in a three-hour live interview and phone-in with [[James Whale (radio)|James Whale]] on the national radio station [[talkSPORT]]. Four days later, Whale announced on his show his intention to stand as UKIP's candidate in the [[London mayoral election, 2008|2008 London Mayoral Election]]. Farage said that Whale "not only has guts, but an understanding of what real people think". Whale later decided not to stand and UKIP was represented by [[Gerard Batten]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ukip.org/ukip_news/gen12.php?t=1&id=2687 |title=London Mayoral Elections |accessdate=24 October 2006 }}{{dead link|date=May 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Farage stood again for the UKIP leadership in 2010 (having stood down the year before, to focus on his unsuccessful campaign for the Buckingham seat) after his successor [[Malcolm Pearson, Baron Pearson of Rannoch|Lord Pearson]] had stood down, and on 5 November 2010 it was announced he had won the leadership contest.{{cite news |work=[[Sky News]] |url=http://news.sky.com/story/817965/nigel-farage-re-elected-ukip-party-leader |title=Nigel Farage Re-Elected UKIP Party Leader |date=5 November 2010 |author=Barnett, Ruth |accessdate=22 November 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121012180508/http://news.sky.com/story/817965/nigel-farage-re-elected-ukip-party-leader |archivedate=12 October 2012 |deadurl=yes }} In May 2014, Farage led UKIP to win the [[European Parliament election, 2014 (United Kingdom)|European Parliament election]] with 4,376,635 votes,{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/events/vote2014/eu-uk-results|title=Vote 2014 Election Results for the EU Parliament UK regions – BBC News|work=bbc.co.uk|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6qNwEjOtM?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/events/vote2014/eu-uk-results|archivedate=11 May 2017}} the first time a UK political party other than Labour or Conservatives had won a national election in over 100 years. Farage was returned as MEP for the South East region, a seat he has represented since 1999. As an MEP, Farage leads the [[Europe of Freedom and Direct Democracy]] grouping in the European Parliament.{{cite web|url=http://www.efdgroup.eu/members|title=Members|work=efdgroup.eu|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150317042838/http://www.efdgroup.eu/members|archivedate=17 March 2015|access-date=2 April 2015}} On 8 May 2015, Farage resigned as leader of UKIP after he failed to win the seat of [[South Thanet (UK Parliament constituency)|Thanet South]] in the general election held the previous day, although he kept open the possibility of re-entering the ensuing leadership contest.{{cite web | title= Nigel Farage resigns as UKIP leader | url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/election-2015-32654046 | author= | date= 8 May 2015 | website= BBC News | accessdate= 11 May 2015 | deadurl= no | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150511010550/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/election-2015-32654046 | archivedate= 11 May 2015 | df= dmy-all }} In his autobiography, ''The Purple Revolution'', he had written: {{quote|It is frankly just not credible for me to continue to lead the party without a Westminster seat. […] Was I supposed to brief Ukip policy from the Westminster Arms? No – if I fail to win South Thanet, it is curtains for me. I will have to step down.{{cite web | title= Farage stays as UKIP leader after resignation rejected | url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-32696505 | author= | date= 11 May 2015 | website= BBC News | accessdate= 11 May 2015 | deadurl= no | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150511154348/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-32696505 | archivedate= 11 May 2015 | df= dmy-all }}}} On 11 May, it was announced that Farage would continue to serve as the party's leader, with the BBC reporting: "Party chairman Steve Crowther said the national executive committee believed the election campaign had been a ‘great success’ and members had ‘unanimously’ rejected Mr Farage's letter of resignation". Interviewed about his continued leadership by the BBC the following day, Farage said: "I resigned. I said I'd resign. I turned up to the NEC meeting with letter in hand fully intending to carry that through. They unanimously said they didn't want me to do that, they presented me with petitions, signatures, statements from candidates saying it would be a bad thing for UKIP. So I left the meeting, went and sat in darkened room to think about what to do, and decided for the interest of the party I would accept their kind offer for me to stay and tear up the letter." He added that he would consider standing for parliament again should a by-election be called in a Labour-held seat.{{cite web| title= Nigel Farage hints at Labour by-election| url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-32710708| author= | date= 12 May 2015| website= BBC News| accessdate= 12 May 2015| deadurl= no| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150513115050/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-32710708| archivedate= 13 May 2015| df= dmy-all}} Farage resigned as UKIP leader on 4 July 2016 with the following comment: "During the [[[Brexit]]] referendum I said I wanted my country back … now I want my life back"{{cite news |last=Mason |first=Rowena |date=4 July 2016 |title=Nigel Farage resigns as Ukip leader after 'achieving political ambition' of Brexit |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/jul/04/nigel-farage-resigns-as-ukip-leader |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London, UK |access-date=4 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160705150119/http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/jul/04/nigel-farage-resigns-as-ukip-leader |archivedate=5 July 2016 }} and added that this resignation was final: "I won’t be changing my mind again, I can promise you",{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-07-04/farage-resigns-as-ukip-leader-adding-to-brexit-political-turmoil |title=Farage Resigns as UKIP Leader After Brexit Vote |last=Kennedy |first=Simon |date=4 July 2016 |website=Bloomberg |publisher=Bloomberg L.P. |access-date=4 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160704100027/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-07-04/farage-resigns-as-ukip-leader-adding-to-brexit-political-turmoil |archivedate=4 July 2016 }} apparently referring to his two previous resignations (in 2009 and 2015).{{cite web |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/07/brexit-ukip-leader-nigel-farage-resigns-160704091835096.html |title=Brexit: UKIP leader Nigel Farage resigns |author= |date=4 July 2016 |website=Al Jazeera English |publisher=Al Jazeera |access-date= |quote=After running divisive campaign to leave the EU, Farage quits, while Britain faces economic and political challenges. |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160704112739/http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/07/brexit-ukip-leader-nigel-farage-resigns-160704091835096.html |archivedate=4 July 2016 }} ===Westminster elections=== Farage had unsuccessfully contested British parliamentary elections for UKIP five times, both before and after his election as an [[Member of the European Parliament|MEP]] in 1999. Under the 2002 European Union decision to forbid MEPs from holding a [[dual mandate]], if he were to be elected to the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]], he would have to resign his seat as MEP. When he contested the [[Bromley and Chislehurst (UK Parliament constituency)|Bromley & Chislehurst]] constituency in a [[Bromley and Chislehurst by-election, 2006|May 2006 by-election]], following the death of Eurosceptic Conservative MP [[Eric Forth]], Farage came third, winning 8 per cent of the vote, beating the Labour Party candidate. This was the second-best by-election result recorded by UKIP out of 25 results, and the first time since the [[Liverpool Walton by-election, 1991|Liverpool Walton by-election]] in 1991 that a party in government had been pushed into fourth place in a parliamentary by-election on mainland Britain. {{cn|date=November 2018}} ===Prince Charles=== [[Charles, Prince of Wales]] was invited to speak to the European Parliament on 14 February 2008; in his speech he called for EU leadership in the battle against [[climate change]]. During the standing ovation that followed, Farage was the only MEP to remain seated, and he went on to describe the Prince's advisers as "naïve and foolish at best."{{cite news|title=UKIP anger at prince's EU speech |work=BBC News |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7245183.stm |date=14 February 2008 |accessdate=8 June 2009 |archivedate=17 February 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080217205903/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7245183.stm |deadurl=no }} Farage continued: "How can somebody like Prince Charles be allowed to come to the European Parliament at this time to announce he thinks it should have more powers? It would have been better for the country he wants to rule one day if he had stayed home and tried to persuade [[Gordon Brown]] to give the people the promised referendum on the [[Treaty of Lisbon]]." The leader of the UK [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]]'s MEPs, [[Gary Titley]], accused Farage of anti-Royalism. Titley said: "I was embarrassed and disgusted when the Leader of the UK Independence Party, Nigel Farage, remained firmly seated during the lengthy standing ovation Prince Charles received. I had not realised Mr Farage's blind adherence to [[right-wing politics]] involved disloyalty and discourtesy to the [[British Royal Family|Royal Family]]. He should be thoroughly ashamed of himself and should apologise to the British people he represents." ===Expenses disclosure=== In May 2009, ''[[The Observer]]'' reported a Foreign Press Association speech given by Farage in which he had said that over his period as a Member of the European Parliament he had received a total of £2 million of taxpayers' money in staff, travel, and other expenses.{{cite news|work=The Observer |date=24 May 2009 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2009/may/24/mps-expenses-ukip-nigel-farage |title=Ukip leader boasts of his £2m in expenses |accessdate=8 June 2009 |first=Toby |last=Helm |location=London |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090527061523/http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2009/may/24/mps-expenses-ukip-nigel-farage |archivedate=27 May 2009 |deadurl=no }} In response, Farage said that in future all UKIP MEPs would provide monthly expense details. ===Herman Van Rompuy=== After the speech of [[Herman Van Rompuy]] on 24 February 2010 to the European Parliament, Farage – to protests from other MEPs – addressed the former [[Prime Minister of Belgium|Belgian Prime Minister]] and first long-term [[President of the European Council]] saying that he had the "charisma of a damp rag and the appearance of low grade bank clerk".{{cite news|date=24 February 2010 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8535121.stm |title=Tirade against 'damp rag' EU president shocks MEPs |work=BBC News |accessdate=24 February 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100225025721/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8535121.stm |archivedate=25 February 2010 |deadurl=no }} Farage questioned the legitimacy of Van Rompuy's appointment, asking, "Who are you? I'd never heard of you, nobody in Europe had ever heard of you." He also asserted that Van Rompuy's "intention [is] to be the quiet assassin of European democracy and of the European nation states".{{cite web|publisher=[[YouTube]]|work=EUX.TV|url=//www.youtube.com/watch?v=bypLwI5AQvY|title=Nigel Farage harangues EU President Herman van Rompuy|accessdate=27 February 2010|date=24 February 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100309210826/http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bypLwI5AQvY|archivedate=9 March 2010}} Van Rompuy commented afterwards, "There was one contribution that I can only hold in contempt, but I'm not going to comment further." After refusing to apologise for behaviour that was, in the words of the [[President of the European Parliament]], [[Jerzy Buzek]], "inappropriate, unparliamentary and insulting to the dignity of the House", Farage was reprimanded and had his right to ten days' allowance (expenses) "docked".{{cite news|title=MEP Nigel Farage fined over 'insulting' tirade |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8544904.stm |work=BBC News |date=2 March 2010 |accessdate=21 March 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100304045601/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8544904.stm |archivedate=4 March 2010 |deadurl=no }}{{cite web|publisher=European Parliament |url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/eng-internet-publisher/eplive/expert/shotlist/20100303SHL92842 |title=EP President Jerzy BUZEK on MEP Nigel FARAGE – 68659 |date=3 March 2010 |accessdate=21 March 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100307164027/http://www.europarl.europa.eu/eng-internet-publisher/eplive/expert/shotlist/20100303SHL92842 |archivedate=7 March 2010 }} Buzek said after his meeting with Farage:
I defend absolutely Mr Farage's right to disagree about the policy or institutions of the [[European Union|Union]], but not to personally insult our guests in the European Parliament or the country from which they may come... I myself fought for free speech as the absolute cornerstone of a democratic society. But with freedom comes responsibility – in this case, to respect the dignity of others and of our institutions. I am disappointed by Mr Farage's behaviour, which sits ill with the great parliamentary tradition of his own country. I cannot accept this sort of behaviour in the European Parliament. I invited him to apologise, but he declined to do so. I have therefore – as an expression of the seriousness of the matter – rescinded his right to ten days' daily allowance as a Member.
Questioned by [[Camilla Long]] of ''[[The Times]]'', Farage described his speech: "it wasn't abusive, it was right." ===2010 UK general election=== On 4 September 2009, Farage resigned as the UKIP's leader to focus on his campaign to become Member of Parliament for [[Buckingham (UK Parliament constituency)|Buckingham]] at [[British Parliament|Westminster]] in the [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|2010 general election]].{{cite news|work=BBC News |date=4 September 2009 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/politics/8237304.stm |title=Farage to quit as leader of UKIP |accessdate=28 April 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090930001212/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/politics/8237304.stm |archivedate=30 September 2009 |deadurl=no }} He later told ''The Times'' journalist Camilla Long that UKIP internal fights took up far too much time.{{cite news|authorlink=Camilla Long |author=Long, Camilla |location=London |newspaper=[[The Sunday Times]] |subscription=yes |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/politics/article7069638.ece |title=Nigel Farage: Brimming over with bile and booze |date=21 March 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110811094714/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/politics/article7069638.ece |archivedate=11 August 2011 |deadurl=no }} Farage stood against sitting Buckingham MP, [[John Bercow]], the newly elected Speaker of the House of Commons, despite the convention that the [[Speaker of the House of Commons (United Kingdom)|Speaker]], as a political neutral, is not normally challenged in his or her bid for re-election by any of the major parties.{{cite news|work=BBC News |date=3 September 2009 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/politics/8235626.stm |title=Farage to stand against Speaker |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090905015156/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/politics/8235626.stm |archivedate=5 September 2009 |deadurl=no }} Farage came third with 8,401 votes. Bercow was re-elected and in second place with 10,331 votes was [[John Stevens (English politician)|John Stevens]], a former Conservative MEP who campaigned as an independent accompanied by "Flipper the Dolphin" (a reference to MPs [[Second home flipping|flipping second homes]]).{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2010/may/07/nigel-farage-ukip-john-bercow |title=Election results: Ukip's Nigel Farage finishes behind John Bercow and Flipper |last=Dowling |first=Tim |work=The Guardian |accessdate=7 May 2010 |location=London |date=7 May 2010 |archivedate=11 May 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100511010455/http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2010/may/07/nigel-farage-ukip-john-bercow |deadurl=no }} ====Injury in air crash==== On 6 May 2010, the morning of the election, Farage was travelling in a two-seater [[PZL-104 Wilga]] aircraft with a pro-UKIP banner attached, when the plane crashed. Farage suffered injuries that were described as non-life-threatening.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/northamptonshire/8664260.stm |title=Nigel Farage injured in plane crash in Northamptonshire |work=BBC News |date=6 May 2010 |archivedate=7 May 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100507191730/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/northamptonshire/8664260.stm |deadurl=no }} Although his injuries were originally described as minor,{{cite news|title=Ukip's Nigel Farage has lucky escape after election stunt plane crash |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/election-2010/7685912/General-Election-2010-Ukips-Nigel-Farage-has-lucky-escape-after-election-stunt-plane-crash.html |date=7 May 2010 |location=London |first=Richard |last=Edwards |accessdate=20 May 2010 |archivedate=10 May 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100510002651/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/election-2010/7685912/General-Election-2010-Ukips-Nigel-Farage-has-lucky-escape-after-election-stunt-plane-crash.html }} his [[Human sternum|sternum]] and ribs were broken and his lung punctured.{{cite news|title=Nigel Farage: born to rant |last=Farndale |first=Nigel |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/politics/ukip/8128877/Nigel-Farage-born-to-rant.html |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=18 November 2010 |accessdate=23 November 2010 |location=London |archivedate=21 November 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101121111516/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/politics/ukip/8128877/Nigel-Farage-born-to-rant.html |deadurl=no }} The [[Air Accidents Investigation Branch]] (AAIB) report said that the aeroplane was towing a banner, which caught in the tailplane, forcing the nose down.{{cite web|accessdate=23 November 2010 |url=http://www.aaib.gov.uk/cms_resources/PZL-104%20Wilga%2035A,%20G-BWDF%2011-2010.pdf|title=AAIB Bulletin: 11/2010 G-BWDF 6 May 2010 at 0659 hrs|publisher=[[Air Accidents Investigation Branch]]}} On 1 December 2010, Justin Adams, the pilot of the aircraft involved in the accident, was charged with threatening to kill Farage in a separate incident. He was also charged with threatening to kill an AAIB official involved in the investigation into the accident.{{cite news|work=BBC News |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-northamptonshire-11886985 |title=Crash pilot 'threatened to kill UKIP's Nigel Farage' |date=1 December 2010 |accessdate=1 December 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101202045231/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-northamptonshire-11886985 |archivedate=2 December 2010 |deadurl=no }} In April 2011, the pilot was found guilty of making death threats. The judge said that the defendant was "clearly extremely disturbed" at the time the offences happened, adding "He is a man who does need help. If I can find a way of giving him help I will."{{cite news|work=BBC News |date=14 April 2011 |accessdate=14 April 2011 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-oxfordshire-13082655 |title=Nigel Farage death threats crash pilot guilty |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110415090431/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-oxfordshire-13082655 |archivedate=15 April 2011 |deadurl=no }} ===May 2012 London mayoral and local elections=== UKIP forgot to put their party name on their candidate's ballot paper for the [[London mayoral election, 2012]],{{cite news|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/blogs/politics/2012/05/how-ukip-became-fresh-choice-london |title=How UKIP became "Fresh Choice for London" |work=[[New Statesman]] |location=London |last=Eaton |first=George |date=4 May 2012 |accessdate=1 June 2012 |archivedate=7 May 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120507012523/http://www.newstatesman.com/blogs/politics/2012/05/how-ukip-became-fresh-choice-london |deadurl=no }} Laurence Webb appearing as "a fresh choice for London". Farage described the mistake as an internal error. Interviewed the following Sunday by [[Andrew Neil]] and asked about "the game plan", Farage welcomed the "average 13% vote" across the country, and stated that the party was preparing for county council elections in 2013, [[European Parliament election, 2014|European elections in 2014]] and a general election in 2015.{{cite news|accessdate=1 June 2012 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-17974787 |title=Nigel Farage calls on Conservative MPs to join UKIP |work=BBC News |date=6 May 2012 |archivedate=9 May 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120509070446/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-17974787 |deadurl=no }} [[File:Nigel Farage talking to the media.jpg|thumbnail|left|Farage at the opening of the UKIP office in [[Basingstoke]], in 2012]] Asked what would happen to UKIP if the Conservatives made a manifesto commitment to a referendum on EU membership, Farage said they had already failed to honour a "cast iron" commitment to a referendum on the [[Lisbon Treaty]]. Challenging Farage's viewpoint, Neil said that UKIP aspired to come top of the European elections, but while UKIP wanted to join the big time they were still seen as "unprofessional, amateur and even unacceptable". In an interview, Farage described [[Sayeeda Warsi, Baroness Warsi|Baroness Warsi]] as "the lowest grade Chairman the Tory Party has ever had". He was voted politician of the year by the [[Online service provider|online service]] [[MSN]].{{cite news|last=Green |first=William |url=http://news.uk.msn.com/uk/ukip%E2%80%99s-nigel-farage-named-top-uk-politician-of-2012 |title=Ukip's Nigel Farage named top UK politician of 2012 |work=MSN News |date=31 December 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130102163318/http://news.uk.msn.com/uk/ukip%E2%80%99s-nigel-farage-named-top-uk-politician-of-2012 |archivedate=2 January 2013 |deadurl=no }} ===May 2013 local elections=== In May 2013, Farage led UKIP to its best-ever performance in a UK election. The party received 23 per cent of the vote in the local elections, winning 147 council seats, and placing it only 2 points behind the governing Conservative Party and 9 points ahead of the Liberal Democrats. Farage was mobbed by well-wishers as he made his way to his favourite pub, the Marquis of Granby, for a celebratory drink.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/ukip/10036463/Local-elections-2013-Nigel-Farages-Ukip-surges-to-best-ever-showing-winning-150-seats.html |title=Local elections 2013: Nigel Farage's Ukip surges to best ever showing, winning 150 seats |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=3 May 2013 |archivedate=4 May 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130504090045/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/ukip/10036463/Local-elections-2013-Nigel-Farages-Ukip-surges-to-best-ever-showing-winning-150-seats.html |deadurl=no }} He called the victory "a real sea change in British politics". Subsequently, polling agency Survation found that 22 per cent of voters intended to support UKIP in the 2015 General Election.{{cite web|url=http://survation.com/2013/05/survation-for-the-mail-on-sunday-reaction-to-the-woolwich-incident/ |title=Survation for the Mail on Sunday, Reaction to the Woolwich incident |publisher=Survation (blog) |date=25 May 2013 |archivedate=15 September 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130915155650/http://survation.com/2013/05/survation-for-the-mail-on-sunday-reaction-to-the-woolwich-incident/ |deadurl=no }} ===Visit to Scotland=== In May 2013, Farage was interrupted by protesters during a press conference in the Canon's Gait pub on Edinburgh's [[Royal Mile]]. The demonstration was organised by groups including the [[Radical Independence Campaign]] and saw protesters vocally accuse Farage of being "racist", "fascist", and a "homophobe", and tell him to "go back to London". Farage made attempts to leave by taxi but was prevented from doing so, and was eventually taken away in an armoured police van while protesters continued to shout.{{cite news|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/odd/nigel-farage-forced-to-flee-edinburgh-s-royal-mile-1-2933645 |title=Nigel Farage forced to flee Edinburgh's Royal Mile |date=16 May 2013 |work=[[The Scotsman]] |location=Edinburgh |accessdate=16 May 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130518024014/http://www.scotsman.com/news/odd/nigel-farage-forced-to-flee-edinburgh-s-royal-mile-1-2933645 |deadurl=no |archivedate=18 May 2013 }}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-22559526 |title=Farage swarmed by angry protesters in Edinburgh |date=16 May 2013 |work=BBC News |accessdate=16 May 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130517014354/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-22559526 |archivedate=17 May 2013 |deadurl=no }}{{cite news|title=Nigel Farage flees barrage of abuse from Edinburgh protesters |last=Carrell |first=Severin |date=16 May 2013 |accessdate=18 May 2013 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2013/may/16/nigel-farage-edinburgh-protesters-van |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |archivedate=17 May 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130517053616/http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2013/may/16/nigel-farage-edinburgh-protesters-van |deadurl=no }} He was trying to raise the profile of UKIP in Scotland ahead of the [[Aberdeen Donside by-election, 2013|Aberdeen Donside by-election]]; the party at that point had no representation in the country, and took 0.91 per cent of the vote in the previous election{{cite news|newspaper=The Herald |location=Glasgow |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/politics/referendum-news/nigel-farage-in-bid-to-woo-scots-voters.2013058317 |title=Farrago as Nigel Farage is rescued by police from protesters |date=16 May 2013 |accessdate=16 May 2013 |archivedate=28 April 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140428041752/http://www.heraldscotland.com/politics/referendum-news/nigel-farage-in-bid-to-woo-scots-voters.2013058317 |deadurl=no }} though it won its first Scottish MEP the following year. During an interview with BBC's ''[[Good Morning Scotland]]'' radio show, Farage labelled the protesters "yobbo fascist scum" before hanging up, stating that the questions regarding the incident in Edinburgh were insulting and unpleasant.{{cite news|date=17 May 2013 |work=BBC News |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-22566180 |title=Nigel Farage blasts 'anti-English' protesters |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130522041113/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-22566180 |archivedate=22 May 2013 |deadurl=no |accessdate=18 May 2013 }} ===2014 European election=== In a second visit to Edinburgh in May 2014 Farage correctly predicted that UKIP would win a Scottish seat in the European Parliament elections. Two hundred protesters heckled and booed him.{{cite news|date=9 May 2014 |work=BBC News |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-scotland-politics-27339519 |title=European election: Farage sure UKIP will win Scotland seat |accessdate=10 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140621233213/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-scotland-politics-27339519 |archivedate=21 June 2014 |deadurl=no }} Thirty police in two vans were needed to preserve order.{{cite news|author1=Gardham, Magnus |author2=Donnelly, Brian |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/politics/referendum-news/police-keep-the-peace-as-ukip-leader-returns-to-edinburgh.24189260 |title=Police keep the peace as Ukip leader returns to Edinburgh |date=10 May 2014 |work=The Herald |location=Glasgow |accessdate=10 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140613021754/http://www.heraldscotland.com/politics/referendum-news/police-keep-the-peace-as-ukip-leader-returns-to-edinburgh.24189260 |archivedate=13 June 2014 |deadurl=no }} In the [[European Parliament election, 2014 (United Kingdom)|European Parliament elections in 2014]], Farage led UKIP to win the highest share of the vote. It was the first time a political party other than the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] and [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] had won the popular vote in a national election since the [[United Kingdom general election, 1906|1906 general election]].{{cite news |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/aad578e8-e463-11e3-a73a-00144feabdc0.html |title=Ukip and Front National lead populist earthquake |work=Financial Times |location=London |date=26 May 2014 |accessdate=31 May 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140531064452/http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/aad578e8-e463-11e3-a73a-00144feabdc0.html |archivedate=31 May 2014 }}{{cite news|title=European Elections: UKIP Tops British Polls |url=http://news.sky.com/story/1268952/european-elections-ukip-tops-british-polls |work=[[Sky News]] |date=26 May 2014 |accessdate=31 May 2014 |archivedate=27 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140527092300/http://news.sky.com/story/1268952/european-elections-ukip-tops-british-polls |deadurl=no }} It was also the first time a party other than the Labour and Conservatives won the largest number of seats in a national election since the [[United Kingdom general election, December 1910|December 1910 general election]].{{cite news|title=UK's Eurosceptic UKIP party storms to victory in Europe vote|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/26/us-eu-elections-britain-idUSBREA4O0EM20140526|agency=Reuters|date=26 May 2014|accessdate=31 May 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140601001848/http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/26/us-eu-elections-britain-idUSBREA4O0EM20140526|archivedate=1 June 2014}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2014/may/26/10-key-lessons-european-election-results |author=Mason, Rowena |title=10 key lessons from the European election results |work=The Guardian |location=London |deadurl=no |date=26 May 2014 |accessdate=31 May 2014 |archivedate=27 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140527052458/http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2014/may/26/10-key-lessons-european-election-results }}{{cite news|title=Lurching Right: UKIP Win Creates Pressure for Cameron and Europe |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/ukip-wins-big-in-britain-and-creates-challenge-for-cameron-and-europe-a-971968.html |work=Der Spiegel |location=Hamburg |date=27 May 2014 |accessdate=31 May 2014 |author=Volkery, Carsten |archivedate=28 May 2014 ===Undeclared gifts=== In June 2014, Farage declared £205,603 for gifts over 10 years, including free use of a barn for his constituency office, which had been declared in the EU register in [[Brussels]] each year. The Electoral Commission said that the gifts should have been also declared in the UK within 30 days of receipt and fined Farage £200.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-27818780 |title=UKIP leader Nigel Farage declares £205,603 in gifts |author=Hawkins, Ross |work=BBC News |date=12 June 2014 |accessdate=12 June 2014 |archivedate=13 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140613021757/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-27818780 |deadurl=no }}{{cite web | url = | archive-date = 28 June 2015}} ===2015 UK general election=== In October 2013, Farage announced on the BBC's ''[[The Andrew Marr Show]]'' that he would stand for election as an [[Member of Parliament|MP]] at the [[United Kingdom general election, 2015]], most likely contesting either [[Folkestone and Hythe (UK Parliament constituency)|Folkestone and Hythe]] or [[South Thanet (UK Parliament constituency)|South Thanet]]; meanwhile he stated that his duty and preference was to focus on his current role as an [[Member of the European Parliament|MEP]].{{cite news|date=6 October 2013 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-24419317 |title=Nigel Farage: I will stand as MP at next general election |accessdate=12 October 2013 |work=BBC News |archivedate=6 October 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131006101317/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-24419317 |deadurl=no }}{{cite news|first=Paul |last=Francis |accessdate=12 October 2013 |url=http://www.kentonline.co.uk/folkestone/news/ukip-leader-could-target-kent-7007/ |title=UKIP leader Nigel Farage could go for Folkestone and Hythe constituency at 2015 election |work=[[Kent Messenger]] |archivedate=6 October 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131006123828/http://www.kentonline.co.uk/folkestone_express/news/ukip-leader-could-target-kent-7007/ |deadurl=no }} In August 2014, Farage was selected as the UKIP [[Prospective parliamentary candidate|candidate]] for [[South Thanet (UK Parliament constituency)|South Thanet]] following local [[husting]]s.{{cite news|title=UKIP's Nigel Farage seeking South Thanet selection |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-28801303 |accessdate=17 August 2014 |work=BBC News |date=15 August 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140816095021/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-28801303 |archivedate=16 August 2014 |deadurl=no }} On 12 September 2014, he appeared at a pro-union rally with Scottish UKIP MEP [[David Coburn (politician)|David Coburn]] ahead of Scotland's [[Scottish independence referendum, 2014|independence referendum]].{{cite news|work=BBC News |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-scotland-scotland-politics-29003017 |title=Scottish independence: Nigel Farage to appear at UKIP pro-Union rally |date=31 August 2014 |accessdate=31 August 2014 |archivedate=31 August 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140831162746/http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-scotland-scotland-politics-29003017 }} In October 2014, Farage was invited to take part in prospective Leaders' debates on BBC, ITV, Channel 4 and Sky ahead of the 2015 General Election.{{cite news|title=UKIP's Nigel Farage invited on leaders' TV debate|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-29595529|accessdate=13 October 2014|work=BBC News|date=13 October 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141013090529/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-29595529|archivedate=13 October 2014}} UKIP indicated that it would consider taking legal action were the [[political party|party]] excluded, in contravention of established [[broadcast media]] rules, from televised Party Leaders' debates in advance of the 2015 General Election.{{cite news|date=31 May 2013 |location=London |last=Wright |first=Oliver |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/nigel-farage-warns-let-ukip-into-studio-for-tv-election-debates-or-ill-take-you-to-court-8640326.html |title=Nigel Farage warns: Let Ukip into studio for TV election debates or I'll take you to court |newspaper=The Independent |deadurl=no |archivedate=1 June 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130601165412/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/nigel-farage-warns-let-ukip-into-studio-for-tv-election-debates-or-ill-take-you-to-court-8640326.html }} The 7-way [[Leaders' debate|Leaders' TV debate]] was broadcast by ITV on 2 April 2015 from [[MediaCityUK]], [[Salford Quays]]. Of three polls taken immediately afterwards, the [[ComRes]] poll had Farage as joint winner, alongside Labour's [[Ed Miliband]] and Conservative [[David Cameron]].{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/general-election-2015/11509641/Leaders-election-debate-Farage-and-Sturgeon-win-says-poll-live-reaction.html|title=Election debate 2015 LIVE: Cameron and Miliband face rival leaders|date=2 April 2015|work=The Daily Telegraph|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150406024613/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/general-election-2015/11509641/Leaders-election-debate-Farage-and-Sturgeon-win-says-poll-live-reaction.html|archivedate=6 April 2015}} In March 2015, Farage declared in his book ''The Purple Revolution'' that he would step down as UKIP leader should he not be elected as an MP; he stated his belief that it would not be "credible" for him to lead UKIP without sitting in [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|parliament at Westminster]].{{cite news|last1=Apps|first1=Peter|title=Nigel Farage will quit as Ukip leader if he fails to win a seat at general election|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/generalelection/nigel-farage-will-quit-as-ukip-leader-if-he-fails-to-win-a-seat-at-general-election-10109927.html|accessdate=16 March 2015|work=The Independent|date=16 March 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150317024620/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/generalelection/nigel-farage-will-quit-as-ukip-leader-if-he-fails-to-win-a-seat-at-general-election-10109927.html|archivedate=17 March 2015}} On 22 March 2015, Farage was targeted by anti-UKIP activists who chased him and his family from a [[pub lunch]] in [[Downe]], [[Kent]]. His daughters ran away to hide and were later found to be safe. Farage, when asked what he thought about the incident, called the protesters "scum".{{cite news|title=London protesters' chase UKIP leader Farage out of pub'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-32009961|accessdate=23 March 2015|work=BBC News|date=22 March 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150322222006/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-32009961|archivedate=22 March 2015}}{{cite news|title=Farage calls anti-Ukip protesters who forced him out of pub 'scum'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/mar/22/farage-calls-anti-ukip-protesters-who-forced-him-out-of-pub-scum|accessdate=29 April 2015|work=The Guardian|date=23 March 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150324095746/http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/mar/22/farage-calls-anti-ukip-protesters-who-forced-him-out-of-pub-scum|archivedate=24 March 2015}} ===2015 resignation announced=== Farage was unsuccessful in his bid to become MP for [[South Thanet (UK Parliament constituency)|South Thanet]]{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/live/2015/may/08/election-2015-live-labour-and-libdems-crushed-in-shock-election-result#block-554c832ae4b0c7299d72ca93 |title=Election live: results day – as it happened |work=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=14 May 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150514154513/http://www.theguardian.com/politics/live/2015/may/08/election-2015-live-labour-and-libdems-crushed-in-shock-election-result#block-554c832ae4b0c7299d72ca93 |archivedate=14 May 2015 }} although he came second (beating Labour by over 4,000 votes), reduced the Conservative majority to less than 3,000, and gained over 32% of the vote. He subsequently announced his resignation as the leader of UKIP, citing that he is a "man of his word" since he promised to resign if he did not win his seat. However, on 11 May 2015, the party chairman said they would not accept Mr Farage's post-election resignation because the party's "election campaign had been a great success".{{cite news |url=http://news.sky.com/story/1481942/ukip-rejects-nigel-farages-resignation |title=UKIP Rejects Nigel Farage's Resignation |work=News.sky.com |date= |accessdate=14 May 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150512164351/http://news.sky.com/story/1481942/ukip-rejects-nigel-farages-resignation |archivedate=12 May 2015 }} A row subsequently developed within the party, in which MEP and campaign chief [[Patrick O'Flynn]] described Farage's public image as "snarling, thin-skinned, aggressive" and said he risked turning the party into a "[[personality cult]]". O'Flynn accused Farage of paying too much attention to advisors that "would like to take UKIP in the direction of some hard-right, ultra-aggressive American Tea Party-type movement", singling out the [[National Health Service (England)|NHS]] and gun control liberalisation as particular issues. [[Raheem Kassam]], Farage's chief of staff and editor of [[Breitbart News#Breitbart London|Breitbart London]] was later sacked as a result, whilst O'Flynn insisted he continued to support Farage as party leader.{{cite news | title= UKIP adviser sacked in Nigel Farage row | url= https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-32734220 | date= 14 May 2015 | work= BBC News | accessdate= 14 May 2015 | deadurl= no | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150517064059/http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-32734220 | archivedate= 17 May 2015 | df= dmy-all }} Farage also faced a number of calls from senior figures within the party to stand down.{{cite web | title= Nigel Farage 'facing a coup' over Ukip leadership | url= https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/may/14/nigel-farage-facing-a-coup-over-ukip-leadership | last= Mason | first= Rowena | date= 14 May 2015 | work= [[The Guardian]] | accessdate= 14 May 2015 | deadurl= no | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150518093055/http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/may/14/nigel-farage-facing-a-coup-over-ukip-leadership | archivedate= 18 May 2015 | df= dmy-all }}
Following the election a UKIP spokesman acknowledged{{cite news|last1=Ward|first1=Alexander|title=UKIP sent insider into protest group|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/ukip-spy-attempted-to-encourage-abuse-nigel-of-farage-and-criminal-damage-10254888.html|accessdate=16 May 2015|work=Independent|date=16 May 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150519025011/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/ukip-spy-attempted-to-encourage-abuse-nigel-of-farage-and-criminal-damage-10254888.html|archivedate=19 May 2015}} that after a series of threatening attacks on Farage it had sent an informant into the Thanet branch of the protest organisation Stand Up to UKIP, stating "in order to provide reasonable security it was of course necessary to have information from the inside", an approach he said was used by "a great many security operations tasked with protecting the safety and wellbeing of a targeted individual". According to ''[[The Guardian]]'', the informant is alleged to have actively encouraged members to commit criminal damage. Farage had said he was the victim of "trade union-funded activists" who were inciting vandalism.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/may/16/ukip-spy-who-infiltrated-protest-group-tried-to-encourage-abuse-of-farage|title=Ukip spy who infiltrated protest group 'tried to encourage abuse of Farage'|author=Rowena Mason|work=The Guardian|date=16 May 2015|accessdate=16 May 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518013753/http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/may/16/ukip-spy-who-infiltrated-protest-group-tried-to-encourage-abuse-of-farage|archivedate=18 May 2015}} ==="Car tampering"=== In January 2016 Farage told ''[[The Mail on Sunday]]'' that he believed his car had been tampered with in October 2015, as he had been forced to stop when his car's wheel nuts came loose. He reported that he had spoken with the [[National Police (France)|French police]] but did not wish to pursue the matter any further.{{cite news|last1=Harley|first1=Nicola|title=Nigel Farage fears he was victim of assassination attempt after motorway crash|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/nigel-farage/12078683/Nigel-Farage-fears-he-was-victim-of-assassination-attempt-after-motorway-crash.html|accessdate=6 January 2016|work=The Daily Telegraph|location=London|date=2 January 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160106050542/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/nigel-farage/12078683/Nigel-Farage-fears-he-was-victim-of-assassination-attempt-after-motorway-crash.html|archivedate=6 January 2016}} ''[[The Times]]'', however, said Farage's story was untrue, and that [[Dunkirk]] prosecutors had no reason to suspect foul play or the police would have started an investigation. The owner of the breakdown garage concerned had said the problem was probably shoddy repair work, but he had been unable to communicate directly with Farage.{{cite news|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/news/politics/article4658534.ece|title=Farage death plot claims rubbished|work=The Times|author=Adam Sage|date=6 January 2016|accessdate=6 January 2016}} Farage later said he had made a "terrible, terrible mistake" in speaking to journalists and that a Sunday newspaper had misreported his claims of tampering as an assassination attempt.{{cite news|last1=McCann|first1=Kate|title=Nigel Farage: I made a 'terrible, terrible mistake' over assassination attempt claims|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/12088804/Nigel-Farage-I-made-a-terrible-terrible-mistake-over-assassination-attempt-claims.html|accessdate=8 January 2016|work=The Daily Telegraph|location=London|date=8 January 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160108215040/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/12088804/Nigel-Farage-I-made-a-terrible-terrible-mistake-over-assassination-attempt-claims.html|archivedate=8 January 2016}} ===Tax avoidance=== Although previously denouncing [[tax avoidance]] in a speech to the [[European Parliament]], in which he attacked European bureaucrats who earned £100,000 a year and paid 12 per cent tax under EU rules,{{cite news|last1=Eaton|first1=George|title=Watch: Nigel Farage denounces tax avoidance in speech last month|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/politics/2013/06/watch-nigel-farage-denounces-tax-avoidance-speech-last-month|work=New Statesman|date=21 June 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160422015706/http://www.newstatesman.com/politics/2013/06/watch-nigel-farage-denounces-tax-avoidance-speech-last-month|archivedate=22 April 2016}} Farage said in 2013 that he had hired a tax advisor to set up the Farage Family Educational Trust 1654, a trust that Farage said was used "for inheritance purposes", on the [[Isle of Man]].{{cite news|last1=Syal|first1=Rajeev|title=Nigel Farage admits setting up tax haven trust fund was a mistake|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2013/jun/21/nigel-farage-tax-haven-trust-fund-mistake|work=The Guardian|date=21 June 2013|language=en-GB|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161226175901/https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2013/jun/21/nigel-farage-tax-haven-trust-fund-mistake|archivedate=26 December 2016}} Farage later described this "as standard practice", but insisted he "decided I didn't want it. I never ever used it. The Isle of Man is not a tax haven."{{cite news|title=Farage gives 'a big no' to publishing tax returns|url=http://morningstaronline.co.uk/a-c614-Farage-gives-a-big-no-to-publishing-tax-returns|accessdate=19 April 2016|work=Morning Star|date=12 April 2016|page=3|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160427221819/http://morningstaronline.co.uk/a-c614-Farage-gives-a-big-no-to-publishing-tax-returns|archivedate=27 April 2016}} Farage has since said that this was a mistake, in part because it cost him too much money, but has criticised the political discourse surrounding tax avoidance as a "[[race to the bottom]]".{{cite news|last1=Mason|first1=Rowena|title=Nigel Farage defends and denies 'straightforward' tax avoidance|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/feb/13/nigel-farage-defends-denies-straightforward-tax-avoidance|accessdate=19 April 2016|work=The Guardian|date=13 February 2015|language=en-GB|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160426233719/http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/feb/13/nigel-farage-defends-denies-straightforward-tax-avoidance|archivedate=26 April 2016}} The [[BBC]] noted that "The Isle of Man was one of the UK's crown dependencies which signed an agreement on corporate disclosure at a recent meeting with David Cameron amid claims that May 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140525202416/http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2013/sep/18/how-fast-is-arctic-sea-ice-melting }} ===Health=== Farage takes an anti-prohibitionist position on recreational drugs. In an April 2014 phone-in interview hosted by ''The Daily Telegraph'' he argued that the [[War on Drugs]] had been lost "many, many years ago", stating that "I hate drugs, I've never taken them myself, I hope I never do, but I just have a feeling that the criminalisation of all these drugs is actually not really helping British society." He argued in favour of a [[Royal Commission]] on drugs, which would explore all avenues as to how to legislate most effectively and deal with their related criminal and public health problems, including the possibility of their [[Drug liberalization|legalisation]].{{cite news|title=Nigel Farage: I've Never Done Drugs, But Legalise Them |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2014/04/04/nigel-farage-ukip-drugs-legalisation_n_5091437.html |accessdate=25 May 2014 |newspaper=Huffington Post UK |date=4 April 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140525195442/http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2014/04/04/nigel-farage-ukip-drugs-legalisation_n_5091437.html |archivedate=25 May 2014 }} According to Farage, the smoking ban in enclosed public spaces is "silly and illiberal"; he recommends separate smoking areas along the lines of some German states. He believes that banning things makes them more attractive to children, and said that "Obesity is killing more people than smoking, you could ban chip shops, you could ban doughnuts. The point is we are big enough and ugly enough to make our own decisions".{{cite news|title=Nigel Farage Says Smoking Ban 'Silly And Illiberal'|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2013/04/30/nigel-farage-smoking-ban-germany-_n_3182909.html|accessdate=19 October 2015|work=Huffington Post|date=30 April 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151216061740/http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2013/04/30/nigel-farage-smoking-ban-germany-_n_3182909.html|archivedate=16 December 2015}} In his 2015 book, Farage reflected that based on his experiences, "the NHS is so over-stretched that if you can afford private health care, you should take it, particularly for diagnostics and preventative medicine. In the NHS, the system is so battered and poorly run that unless you are really lucky, you will fall through the cracks. The NHS is, however, astonishingly good at critical care. But what testicular cancer taught me is that the NHS will probably let you down if you need screening, fast diagnosis and an operation at a time that suits you". He supports reform within the NHS, saying that its resources have become stretched due to increased immigration, and blaming Labour for high costs of new hospitals built through private finance initiatives. Farage says that money which the NHS could spend on treating taxpayers with serious conditions is instead spent on recent immigrants with [[HIV]], an opinion which has been controversial. A [[YouGov]] poll found 50 per cent of those taking part to support Farage, with 37 per cent saying that he is scaremongering.{{cite news|last1=Gander|first1=Kashmira|title=Nigel Farage on the NHS: Half of voters agrees that HIV patients cost UK too much money|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/health-and-families/health-news/nigel-farage-on-the-nhs-half-of-voters-agrees-that-hiv-patients-cost-uk-too-much-money-10158767.html|accessdate=10 April 2015|work=The Independent|date=6 April 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150409203039/http://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/health-and-families/health-news/nigel-farage-on-the-nhs-half-of-voters-agrees-that-hiv-patients-cost-uk-too-much-money-10158767.html|archivedate=9 April 2015}} ===Independence Day national holiday=== Farage has argued strongly in favour of a British Independence Day being observed within the United Kingdom, on 23 June each year. |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-eu-referendum-36613295 |title=EU Referendum: Farage declares 'independence day' |publisher=BBC News |date=24 June 2016 |deadurl=no The show is broadcast live on Mondays to Thursdays from 6{{nbsp}}pm to 7{{nbsp}}pm.{{cite web|url=http://www.lbc.co.uk/radio/presenters/nigel-farage/|title=LBC|website=LBC|accessdate=19 June 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170618041612/http://www.lbc.co.uk/radio/presenters/nigel-farage/|archivedate=18 June 2017}} Also, since September 2017, Farage has hosted an additional new show on LBC, ''The Nigel Farage Show On Sunday'', which is broadcast live every Sunday from 10{{nbsp}}am to 12{{nbsp}}noon. Since March 2018, Farage has hosted a new podcast under the LBC banner entitled ''Farage Against The Machine'', a [[play on words]] for the term 'rage against the machine', where Farage discusses the latest political developments and political news with political figures who he both agrees, and disagrees with. New episodes of the podcast are released every Friday. The podcast is available from almost any podcast player via that players search bar.{{cite web|url=http://www.lbc.co.uk/radio/podcasts/farage-against-the-machine-lbcs-new-podcast/|title=Farage Against The Machine: Nigel Farage's New Podcast For LBC|publisher=|accessdate=29 March 2018}} {{Clear}} ==Personal life== [[File:Nigel Farage.jpg|upright|thumb|Farage attending the [[2009 Ashes series]] at [[Lord's Cricket Ground]]]] Farage lives in [[Single Street]],{{cite web|title=Surrey County Council – MEP details – Nigel Farage MEP|url=https://mycouncil.surreycc.gov.uk/mgUserInfo.aspx?UID=458|website=Surrey County Council|accessdate=23 January 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202014825/https://mycouncil.surreycc.gov.uk/mgUserInfo.aspx?UID=458|archivedate=2 February 2017}} a hamlet in the [[London Borough of Bromley]], "around the corner from his mother". He has been married twice. In 1988, he married Irish nurse Gráinne Hayes, with whom he has two children: Samuel (born 1989) and Thomas (born 1991). The couple divorced in 1997. In 1999, he married Kirsten Mehr, a German national; the couple have two children.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/?xml=/news/2007/03/11/nukip11.xml |title=Making plans with Nigel |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=11 March 2007 |location=London |first=Robert |last=Watts |accessdate=20 May 2010 |archivedate=26 September 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130926153721/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/?xml=%2Fnews%2F2007%2F03%2F11%2Fnukip11.xml |deadurl=no }} His wife told the [[Press Association]] in February 2017 that the couple were living "separate lives" and Farage "moved out of the family home a while ago".{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-38879101|title=Nigel Farage and wife Kirsten 'living separate lives'|work=BBC News|date=6 February 2017|accessdate=6 February 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170206141144/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-38879101|archivedate=6 February 2017}} He has spoken of how his children have been teased because of their relation to him. In a BBC interview with [[Rachel Johnson]] in May 2017 he described himself as "53, separated, skint [broke]", citing 20 years of campaigning as the reason for both.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/av/uk-politics-40047762/nigel-farage-i-m-separated-i-m-skint|title=Nigel Farage: I'm separated, I'm skint|work=BBC News|accessdate=19 June 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170619215256/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/av/uk-politics-40047762/nigel-farage-i-m-separated-i-m-skint|archivedate=19 June 2017}} He has made reference to his German wife in response to criticisms that he is somehow "anti-Europe", while he himself says he is merely anti-EU. Farage has employed his wife as his [[European Parliament|parliamentary]] secretary{{cite news|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |last=Holehouse |first=Matthew |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/ukip/10780516/Nigel-Farage-no-Briton-could-work-as-hard-as-my-German-wife.html |title=Nigel Farage: no Briton could work as hard as my German wife |location=London |date=22 April 2014 |accessdate=22 April 2014 |archivedate=22 April 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140422180605/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/ukip/10780516/Nigel-Farage-no-Briton-could-work-as-hard-as-my-German-wife.html |deadurl=no }} and in April 2014 he explained that "nobody else could do that job".{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-27116110 |title=UKIP immigration policy – the wife test |last=Robinson|first=Nick|authorlink=Nick Robinson (journalist)|work=BBC News |date=22 April 2014 |accessdate=23 April 2014 |archivedate=28 April 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140428042848/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-27116110 |deadurl=no }} On 25 November 1985, Farage was hit by a car after a night out, and suffered injury to his head and left leg, the latter nearly requiring amputation. He was in casts for 11 months, but recovered, and the nurse who treated him became his first wife.{{cite news|last1=Farage|first1=Nigel|title=Nigel Farage: A car crash nearly killed me, but at least I got a wife out of it|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/nigel-farage/11466527/Nigel-Farage-A-car-crash-nearly-killed-me-but-at-least-I-got-a-wife-out-of-it.html|accessdate=10 April 2015|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=13 March 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150416154302/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/nigel-farage/11466527/Nigel-Farage-A-car-crash-nearly-killed-me-but-at-least-I-got-a-wife-out-of-it.html|archivedate=16 April 2015}} On 26 December 1986, Farage first felt symptoms of what was later discovered to be [[testicular cancer]]. He had the left testicle removed, and the cancer had not spread to any other organs. In 2010, Farage published a memoir, entitled ''Fighting Bull'' (''Flying Free'' in paperback), outlining the founding of UKIP and his personal and political life so far.{{cite book
